reviewText:
This game has been on my wishlist for a long time. I was just waiting for it to emerge from Early Access to pick it up. Well today is that day and I have to say - it still feels like an Early Access game. I read a number of the other reviews and they just don't feel genuine to me, based on my experience in the game.

The user interface is clunky at best. For instance, they have a text based Tutorial in game that you can call up at any time, as well as some hints when playing. The hints say use the 'Action Button' to perform an action. Fair enough - but what's the Action Button mapped to? Ok, pull up the Options menu and look for keybindings...nope! You have to save your game and back out to the main menu just to look at the keybindings. Not a deal breaker but pretty annoying when you are first learning the game.

Next up - they have mini-quests you can complete (like sell 5 health potions) for experience. Great! I chose an easy quest and was on my way. But there are other quests you can choose too. So I pick a second one to optimize my time. Except when you select it you replace the original, without any prompt warning you that you lose all progress on the existing quest. Ugh.

Some pretty clear bugs in the UI, like looking at the skills. A hint says to select a skill to see its description and cost. Except it doesn't work. You click on the icon and it just asks you if you want to buy the skill without telling you the cost or the description.

Then there's the gameplay. Let's be fair I only played an hour so I didn't see very much. But that first hour was dreadfully boring. Purchase a display, purchase an item to put on the display, open the shop and literally watch the shop to see if any customers (or thieves) come in to do business. For 15 minutes you just stand there waiting to see if any customers come in. I'm sure there's much more to the game after this, but after an hour of just staring at the screen waiting for customers to buy I couldn't take it. This is only a $10 game, but it just isn't fun in the current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Recommended for potential
The game still needs some more polish to be pleasantly playable. At the moment you cannot close your shop so that you may change some things around, instead you have to save your game then reopen it. This is the only major complaint; a smaller one would be that there are things that indicate features that just haven’t been added yet (for example a quest board with nothing on it).

Now for the, as I mentioned earlier, potential. Some features that I feel would make the game much more interesting include:
-	Employees (people to sweep the floors or security).
-	Hero’s that enter your store and make custom requests for a quest they might have taken on.
-	Some more random events ( e.g. people vandalizing your store)
-	A store quality rating
-	Decorations for your store (paintings, vases or chandeliers)
-	Some more creative shop expansions (a second floor or balconies)
Apart from all this I really can’t wait to see the future of this game and all it has to offer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This has been provided to me for free for review purposes.OverviewShoppe Keep is a cute indie game where you roleplay as a well.. shopkeeper! You have complete freedom over what you will have in stock, where you will put them, and so on. You are the only employee, so you'll need to do everything from furniture placement, ordering products, restocking, cleaning and maintenance, and even guarding your shop from raiders and thieves!

The Pros:Sandbox - While there are some quests to guide you, but you are free to do what you wish. You are in charge of all the aspects of your shop.

Play Style - You play from day to day (no weekends :D) and each day is divided into different stages, namely two five minute intervals, in which you will have to pay taxes. Visitors are realistically peaking during the middle of the day and low at the start and end of the day. Between any two days, you have an unlimited amount of time to clean and restock your shop!

Fun! - Even though the game play is repetitive from day to day, the profits that you make allow you to expand, and afford to import better loot. You will find yourself enjoying the seemingly monotonous activities because you will expand your shop, have more expensive items in stock, attract more clients, make more profits in a perpetual way.

Humorous - The voice acting for the villagers is quite cute. Especially when they scream What the F#&@ when they stumble upon a high price or the joy they experience after making a purchase. Shopping, shopping, shoppng, YAY!
The Cons:Performance Hit at later stages - When your shop will become bigger

reviewText:
Early Access Review

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nqzf96VTonU

*UPDATE* The devs have been cracking out update after update getting Shoppe Keep in way better shape than the pre-release build. Some of this review may be outdated! :D This is a good thing.

I loved Recettear, so when Shoppe Keep got on my radar I was really excited.  It's in Alpha still and is fully playable.  This game does as much right as it does wrong.  Is it fun? Yes it is, once you climb over a huge hump to get to a productive endless mode.

The good:
-Running a shop in first person is great, it really feels like you are juggling all the workings of a busy store by yourself
-Lots of useful skill upgrades that are earned by turning over product and earning XP
-Shoplifters are a big problem and you can whip out both sword and spell to make them regret stealing (...with this arsenal why are you running a shop, again? O_o)
-Place shelves and tables as you like (if you can afford them) to make a shop that is all your own
-Mark up and mark down product on the fly (Honestly I stayed at 150% the entire time with no problems)
-Rapid fire placing products out is satisfying
-Tons of Scenarios to play through where you have to meet objectives and earn rewards
-The peasants have a cool style to them and I love the skeletons when you zap a shoplifter
-The blocky potions are awesome looking!

The Bad:
-Sweeping. Unless you are the worlds biggest Viscera Cleanup fan this mechanic may drive you nuts as you have to clean up after all these filthy peasants tracking mud all over
-Scenarios are mandatory if you want to have a wide variety of items to sell in endless mode
-The gameplay drags on forever sometimes.  Each game day is 20 minutes long in endless mode
-The hitbox when fighting is a joke, I rarely can kill JUST the shoplifter without ending 1-3 other innocents and taking a big gold penalty for my troubles (this is factoring in the skill that is supposed to help and the security grid!)
-When a shoplifter is killed by the door and that 350 gold armor falls outside your reach T_T
-Needs more stuff to sell!
-Various graphic glitches (floaty out of sync arms/legs, stretchy corpse meshes)
-Needs a more streamlined tutorial built into the first couple scenarios rather than having you read the help window

Final Verdict: Shoppe Keep is fun when you get past some pretty big obstacles.  But it always felt like a game with a lot of promise but just wasn't there yet.  Still, you could do a lot worse and under the assumption this game will still be updated and developed you may want to give it a spin.

reviewText:
If managing the shop that adventurers frequent so often in classic RPGs sounds like fun, this game is for you. You'll be in charge of building your shop from the ground up, managing inventory, sending your champion on quests to get rare materals, and defending against barbarians.

Pros    Developer is very active and listens to the community. Check out gameplay from a year ago to see just how far the game has come in a short time.
Very free form in how you manage your store. There's no 'right' or 'wrong' way to play.
Tons of items to stock, with more being added with each update.
Skill point system with lots of things to unlock.
After the first hour gameplay gets very hectic.
A few different mechanics for acquiring items to keep things interesting.
The graphics, while simple, are charming and the game has a good sense of humor.
Cons    The UI and some of the mechanics are still a bit rough. Thankfully there are tutorials and a wiki to help.
There's not an end game" that I'm aware of.
Very resource intensive. Runs well enough on my GTX 760

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just an amazing game that keeps getting better.  The controls are great, the graphics aren't bad for an Alpha-level game and the concept is totally new and interesting.

Plus, you don't just play as the person selling weapons and gear.  You can use upgraded versions to fend off barbarians that attack the town from time to time.

Definitely a game you should try.

-----------Added to review 18 Feb 2016---------------

The skills menu allows you to upgrade your shoppe, your keeper's skills (such as how much your customers will tolerate as far as prices, how often thieves try to steal things, which types of items you can use to display items, which classes of characters visit your store, which tier of items you have available for purchase for those classes, which rooms are available to you to use, how much money you make off transactions, etc etc etc.

The furniture you are able to build to hold your items for people to buy (displays) come in all different sizes and shapes.  It's really a matter of personal preference.  So, you really get to build the shop YOU want to build.

There's a farm out back that's been fixed so you can grow items to sell also.

Your champion (you are able to purchase them through the skills menu) can go adventuring and loot things for you to sell in your store.  Some things you can't get any other way.

There are now trashcans you can sift through in the town that usually contain items you can sell also.

There is a section called customize" on the main menu where you can buy and equip new weapons
date: spells and tools to your shoppe keeper.  The different spells have different types of areas of effect
recommended: etc.\n\nUpdate:  A patch has been created to change some of the behavior of the patrons.  They no longer throw things around the store as often when they are upset about how much an item costs."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is very addicting, and satisfying.
https://youtu.be/s1EHVcKJGH8
The idea is that you play as the NPC you always see running shops in RPG games. You buy stock for items, choose the price  and profit you will be making from the item, build your shop, sell to customers. Sounds simple enough, but there are a lot of aspects that make the game very interesting.

You can actually set your prices too high, that way customers won't purchase your items, and sometimes even slap them off their spot. Why? Because they're ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
Occasionally you'll get a sneaky bugger that thinks they're smart, and they'll try to steal one of your items. If you act quick enough, you can slash at them with your sword, or zap them with magic. All the customers in your shop will run away at this point, but atleast you got your item back.

Keeping your shop clean is also something you need to keep an eye on. All these filthy NPCs don't wipe their boots at the door, so everywhere they walk, they leave filth. You will be inspected every now and again, so it's best you sweep all the dirt, and corpses off of the floor.

There are a lot of items to buy, each are sought out by differnt types of customers. Commoners, adventurers, mages, etc.

You can also upgrade your character permanently across all levels with points. You earn these points by leveling up, which is basically by doing everything. You can grab upgrades like Gain 10% more money from purchases"
date: "Faster delivery of items" or "Anti-thief barrier".\n\nThere are 2 modes to choose from as it is. You can choose "Scenarios" which is almost a story mode. You play one mission

reviewText:
In depth.

The worst thing about this game is how horrendously poorly it starts off and presents itself. In that first hour of play, I was VERY tempted to claim a refund. I didn't feel any satisfaction in being a shop keeper, I had no idea what I was doing, there was very little in terms of tutorial (a note, text on pages will never be a good tutorial - give me prompts when starting out and you'll convey how to play the game more quickly and easily to the user), and I only had 3-4 customers coming by to buy health potions in the first few days.

Then the second hour hit. Then the window of a refund closed, and funnily enough, so did my desire to claim one. Then the third hour hit. Apparently the fourth has also hit but I have no awareness of that, I was too busy sweeping and restocking. Now it's far too late and I want to sleep, but not before praising the game.

If you ever wanted to be a retail worker who can brandish a sword and slaughter a thief or even just a rude customer, this is for you. The game is exceptionally good at simulating the busy shop nature. I have to stock so many of these items, but suddenly someone is stealing something, then some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ customer throws a shield, dirt is accumulating, my chest pieces are now out, my delivery of swords is in but all of a sudden no one wants swords they want armor, oh someone else is stealing, oh I thought someone was stealing but they were just running after I murdered the first thief now I'm an actual murderer, oh but the gloves are out as well...

Things get hectic. And it's pretty fun gameplay.

As I implied above, the biggest things to improve are:

• Tutorials that aren't trash. It's so commonplace to put a tutorial at the beginning that having a separate section handle it seems alien. Also a dozen pages of texts does not make a great tutorial. It was enough to get my feet wet but I'd much prefer button prompts in the first day. Push 1
date: now left click on the table to place your health potions" etc. It might not feel important
recommended: but with the 2 hour window for refunds
hoursPlayed: you should strive to set a better first impression. Throwing the user into the fray is a game mechanic for some games
voteText:
but this isn't Dark Souls: Shop edition.

• Better UI. It's a bit of a mess when looking at all the skill pages. Part of the reason starting off needs a better tutorial is the skill pages overwhelms a new player a bit. There's a ton of crap all over the place. It should just be one page.

• Better overall interface. The game feels pretty amateurish. If you've played Town of Salem or some other browser game now on steam

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to Sweep Simulator 2015! After setting up shoppe in a little quaint town, you soon find out that everyone is Pigpen from Peanuts. As you follow around every customer walking into your store, you try to sweep away all the grime left behind because it ruins the appeal of your shoppe. To no avail, the dirt never stops and neither does the sweeping you will have to do.... (Thanks to the devs for reducing the dirt intake of customers, so the tale above is just a horrible memory.)
:POSITIVE ASPECTS:
-Animation that isn't too complex, but complements the style of the game.
-3 skill trees to level up your shoppe, deliver time, and prices.
-Customers stealing and barbarians attacking keeps you on your toes.
-Can strike down all who oppose you or look at you wrong!
-Customers actually pick up or wear the items they buy.
-More variation than most game's npcs (add hooded rogue like characters maybe?).
-Multiple types of swords, spells, brooms, and hammers to buy as you progress.
-Mideveal/Fantasy style of the game is wonderful.
-2 game modes. Scenarios (Story line) and My shoppe (manage your own shoppe with no rules!).
-Building and customizing your shoppe is very flexible in terms of how you can place shelves, tables, counters, etc.
-You can see your character's legs when you look down and realize why you became a shoppe keeper.
-Mice appear when your shoppe is really dirty (not very positive, but a cool feature).
-You can finally walk around outside your shoppe and pursue thieves.
-Day and night cycles.
-Sombreros
-ONLY 7 DOLLARS!!!
:NEGATIVE ASPECTS:
-Sword combat is a little clunky. May hit/kill an innocent or damage/destroy a table next to you while stabbing a barbarian infront of you.
-Npcs are a little stupid and get caught on things like shelving units, tables, each other, and decide to do a moonwalk at times. (Please make Billie Jean play when NPCs moonwalk. Jk.)
-No Steam trading cards
-No Steam Workshop (Srsly guys, would be the bomb.)
:COMMENTS:
Charming game with so much potential. Can't wait to see how this game progresses over time. Of corse I will be playing often and checking out all the new updates. 9/10.

reviewText:
tldr: I got it for $8 and spent 50 hours on it. It's good, simple fun. Lots of issues, some can be forgiven, others not so.

6.5/10 - if it's under $10? It's worth it.

** THE BONES OF IT **

Once you get over the initial (and I have to be honest) clumsy UI this game becomes good fun. Once you tweak the graphics, read the tutorials and adjust the UI slider so you can read anything, this game becomes fun. Once you get past the fact that despite having opened a shop you have to walk the streets to sell your Health Potions to get started, this game becomes fun....

Define FunAnyone who has ever owned a business or even made sales via eBay knows the thrill of getting your first, then second then third customer. and this game does that nicely.

There are a lot of upgrades (poorly presented mind) and tiered products that open up your offerings. From leather to plate to wood to Stealth to Wizard.... There is a reasonable number of shelving and display options, also requiring unlocking.

Progression is nicely balanced. Your items become unlocked as your furniture becomes unlocked, and your automated bot systems become unlocked and your earnings allow you to open the shop up... See where I'm going... It's a nice smooth path.

Hire a Champion" and it can be made to do missions to bring back items

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I liked the look of this game it looked like something fresh and something different.
Fresh and different is what I got here.
I started playing and 9 hours later I realised its time for bed.
Ok its in Early Access so some bugs are to be expected.
However the game runs very well, no crashes and I never experenced any game breaking bugs in the 9 hours I played.

My first 15 minutes of gameplay I lost track of how many times I shouted the word B*stard at the balding dude running out the door of my shop with a Mana Potion! Me still only learning the bloody controls so alls I could do is watch him in horror as he made off with my item,with only a broomstick in my hand.

So Pros and Cons

Pros
+Stable for Alpha
+Fun (Sweeping,Ordering,Selling,Building,Maintaining)
+It made me laugh
+Upgrade Trees feel impactful
+Graphics
+Music

Cons
-I find the Melee Attack tends to cause more trouble then its worth I stick with the magic because if I swing my sort I normally take out people I dont intend to.


What this game needs to be perfect?
-Devs to listen to there fans :)
-Tons and Tons more items to sell.
-Better variety of charater models.
-More crafting options.
-polished combat
-And ultimately a way to make freeplay mode never ending let us expand as much as we want dont cap that on us.


Oh and probly should mention you get all this for €4.99??

This game is a steal  buy it :)

Have you ever wondered while playing an RPG inside a weapon or armor shop, I wonder how it would be to have this job?".

Well this game is exactly the answer to that question. More or less of course. This game has the elements of running a business. You don't necessarily have to sell armor and weapons. You can be versatile in your store such as
hoursPlayed: different types of seeds to grow
voteText: and the helper bot. There is currently one game mode you can play with and that's called "My Shoppe". Here you basically set up your shop the way you see fit and earn money. Starting the game off is a little slow though as you only have little income and can order potions to start. You can buy some pedestals and sell your potions that way. Eventually you'll earn enough money to buy and sell things at a higher price.  Selling items are easy. Keeping track of what's missing
helpfulPercent: and when to order them is another thing. Currently in the game you can talk to the customer and see what they are interested in buying so if you have it stock put it out for sale! votesHelpful: "This is way too expensive for my taste

(ZAP! is my personal favorite). Don't forget about the Barbarians either! As your shop does well you will experiance random waves of Barbarians. Sometimes you get only one. Sometimes you get six. It's up to you to defend your shop. If you're interested in giving yourself a challenge or a quest" then you can do so! Quests such as "Sell X amount of these certain shields" and earn yourself 1

000 Gold. Let's not forget the Skyrim references in this game!

So in all these pros weigh out the cons. I believe this game to be fun at it's state and obviously it being an early access game there is much to be added and fixed! reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I booted up the game, at 11 p.m then I started playing. I complained a bit about how slow it felt a bit at the beginning then I started to get the hang of it. Next thing You know it was 4 a.m and I was running a pimped out organized shop with corpses outside that I can't clean up due to boundaries with a fat wallet.

The game is good is just the task of high maintenance and making sure your valuables don't get stolen. Plus constantly sweeping the dirt and grime these filthy adventureres leave in your Shop is disgraceful! Building and organizing everything in your prefered order and making profits! Eventually wondering why plated armor is less than wood armor and why  does weed do more damage than a sword itself but eventually you stop questioning it. Fighing those foolish enough to challenge a man with lightning to protect your shop as everyone else panics, very satisfying.

Pros:
-Feels Like Your Own Shop
-Very easy to learn
-Multitasking Skills
-The Music No More Need Be Said
-Very in Depth For Early Access

Cons:
-Bots AI a Tad Sluggish
-Weird Boundaries due to Invisible Walls
-Voice of Customers Barely Audible
-Not Always Visually Appealing

Bugs:
-Customer Stuck Walking in Place after Purchase
-Skeleton Goes Insane Stretching Everywhere after Lightning Blast
-Pricing System Changes the prices of other Items based off Percentage Not Only Held Item

Suggestions:
-Be Able To Take Back Items From the Cauldron & Adventurer
-Much more Variety in Items
-More Alchemy Type Items Such as Potions EIther You Brew or FInd
-More Brand of Armor Accesible from Shop
-Different Weapon Types & Possibly a Blacksmith Experience along with Creating Weapons with Stats by Materials
-Set price System
-Customizeable Equipment for Yourself
-Recipe Pages for Items to Make
-Slow Phases of the Day Time Length Cut in Half

reviewText:
Early Access Review

v 0.13.5889.27315
This game is very necessary, it's almost criminal how little RPG shop games that are available. If you like putting things on shelves and moving tables around, you'll almost definitely enjoy this game.

Pros:
- Developers are very active with updates, they listen and learn from the community constantly.
- Adjustable Item Selling Prices.
- Good minimalistic graphics on nearly all items.
- The male shopper's voices, they're fantastic on a Fable level of humour.
- Champions, basically letting you having a little mini RPG adventure in the midst of running the shop.
- Shopkeeper Progression.

(As of Right Now) Cons:
- Drastic frame rate drops when a lot of shoppers are present, probably due to item density.
- AI pathing issues, mostly due to shopper collision.
- Lack of diversity in show tables.
- The Storage Chest is a portal into lag hell, I'd recommend not using it at all for large quantities of items.
- (WARNING) Skellingtons.

Things I'd like to see in the future.
- Steam Workshop/Mod Support, as I see it there's only so much the developers should do themselves on a game like this, I feel like modding could expand the game a lot.

reviewText:
This game released only recently so there may be improvements between the time I'm writing this and the time you're reading it. Written shortly after release out of Early Access. I had previously had long paragraphs explaining what's going on with each feature, but I will try to condense this as much as possible. I will write a second, optional part of the review you can read for more detail.

This is a game I legitimately enjoy, but has too many lingering issues for me to recommend it in its current state. Here are some positives (+) and negatives (-).

(+) Customers: You can have over 1000 unique customers and so far the number keeps increasing, each saves what they are wearing and holding as they buy items. Very cool!

(+) Customization: Shop is very customizable and modular, change shopkeeper look and gender on main screen.

(+) Automation via Robots: These are a godsend as the size of your shop increases, marking each individual spot for restock is a pain but once it's working it makes your job way easier and watching them at work is fun! TIP: Adjust stock bot price in lower right of bot menu, make sure star is highlighted so it restocks marked shelves properly.

(-) Crafting, Grinder and Champion: Use the champion and grinder to get items and crafting rescources. However, it's ultimately not worth the time and money and feels like an incomplete feature.

(-) Gardening: You can unlock a garden in the back of your shop, but it has no real depth or end-game use. There are only three seeds to buy and plant and can't be grinded into anything useful.

(-) Performance: Huge memory hog despite seemingly rudamentary graphics, occaisional fps hiccups. Even on low and with a monster PC. (EDIT: New performance slider added, effectiveness untested since writing.)

(-) UI: Inventory is shown as a 1 block wide vertical bar, you have to scroll a lot and you can even scroll above the 1st item of your inventory. (EDIT: Scroll issue has been fixed.) Some parts of UI are on a wall in the shop or only accessable from the main menu.

-The Fun-: It's what's kept me playing the game despite all these issues. Huge timesink game, sandbox-y with no plot. It's fun watching a huge amount of customers going in and out to upgrade their gear, watching your automated bots take care of most of the work, and customizing your shop.

-The Bad-: Lots of seemingly unfinished features and lack of polish, tons of technical issues, inefficient use of computer rescources.

-The Verdict-: Regardless of all the bumpiness, I've still enjoyed this game. It's just important that you understand what you're getting into and what to expect. As of the time this review was published, I would advise looking into other shop sim games.

----You can stop reading here, but I have more details below.----

Customization PT.2: Customizing your shop is fun, but it can also be a headache. Even with a fully expanded shop, you will have to manage your space very carefully if you want to fit everything in at end-game. Objects placed on racks and tables have their own individual collision, meaning that a space you could previously pass through is now blocked by an item itself, requiring you to re-adjust your setup. You can shift-click in order to snap tables to a grid, but if you want to keep everything compressed, you'll need to carefully adjust everything pixel by pixel.

Crafting, Grinder and Champion PT.2: The issues holding back the crafting system are multitude. Recipes are very few and very specific. Not only do you need to correctly combine four ingredients, but you have to in a specific order or items are lost. This means there is basically no way you are going to discover a recipe on your own through experimentation, and will have to look at a wiki. There is even an item called a torn recipe page, this has no in-game function (and as far as I can tell does not even have a real recipe on it).

The second set of issues are difficulty and cost in aquiring these materials, many recepies require huge amounts of a single grinded element, or a rare item that you only have a small chance of aquiring from a champion quest, and then only one at a time. Do champion levels increase number of items gained and chance? I couldn't tell you any difference with a level 20 champ. The items gained from a quest do not come close to covering the costs on sending them out on the quest in the first place.

All these elements combined with a low price increase for crafted items, they could only be profitable when mass produced, which in most cases just isn't possible. There may be some setups that allow you to grind up ordered items into the ingredients needed, but to know whether or not it's worth it would require a lot of math or looking at a guide for someone who's already done it.

Save Files: Game saves are actually seperated into two different files in two different places. At first glance, everything is saved in the .sk file in your game directory, but that actually only covers the shop itself and customers. Seperately saved is your character profile, which keeps track of data for achievements, bought upgrades like hammers and ALL of your skill points and skills. This second part is kept -in the registry-. So if you wanted to back-up all of your save, you would also have to create a windows registry back up. There is no cloud saving for this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Originally picked Shoppe Keep up because it was on sale, and because it looked good. Glad to see I wasn't disappointed. Aggravating customers that like to dirty my shop and throw my wares around aside, its a very addicting little game where the only thing you have to do is run a shop. Simple, right? At first, certainly. But then you get more and more customers in different classes that all need different things. But you only have so much room in your shop right now, because you haven't quite reached that amount of coin where you're able to break down another wall. Obviously, you've got to stock a little of everything.

Keep an eye on your wares, kill any thieves that try to sneak off with your stock, and be ready to deal with aggravating customers that will regularly call you peasant, curse the prices you've set, and fling your items into the air with great abandon. They do it twice if you unlock the right skill!

I'm not sure what the rest of the game will hold, but I'm looking forward to it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although it's not one of my favorite games, Shoppe Keepe kept me entertained for quite a while. If you're into incremental and micro-management type games, I'd recommend it to you. It can be boring after a while if you're not into the genre, but if you are, it's defiently worth the $7.

Pros:
-Variety of items you can sell that different people will buy
-Popularity of different items fluctuates over time
-Customers each have a different interest and return to your shop
-Shop is expandable
-Lots of furniture and customizability with placement
-You choose which items to import and resell at what price
-Somewhat of a skill tree with different perks that you unlock
-Neat alchemy system by grinding up items you buy into their components and then re-crafting them into something else
-UI is simple and easy to use
-Thieves also steal from your shop at some times, you can hunt them down
-Taxes based on how much you own
-You can equip your own adventurer with items and send him on journeys to find special items

Cons:
-Graphics aren't bad, but they're not stunning too
-Map outside your shop is a little limited, customers appear and disappear when reaching map borders
-Some things are a little confusing, i.e., helperbot
-Alchemy system gives nearly no hints, although this is fine for some people, you're left basically guessing what the ingredients are as you don't even know what kind of products you can make
-No buying raw materials for alchemy, you have to buy finished products and then grind them down
-A glitch and a bug once every now and then, but nothing game breaking

Overall, a fun game if you're into the playstyle and definetly worth the $7 if you are. Of course, it's still in Early Access, so more content is on the way. 8/10, fun game to play, would recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my opinion Shoppe Keep is a very fun game that takes alot of cognitive work and multitasking, especially when you first start out. (excluding the 3 hours of ingame time of pure sweeping) I am going to present a list of my personal Pros/Cons of this very new game.
PROS__________

1. Presents a whole new and interesting perspective of gaming
2. Has manageable scenarios/tutorials that provide challenges
3. Has a Personal shoppe mode allowing you to create your own store
4. Takes cognitive work and planning to succeed
5. Decent graphics/animations on the NPCs
6. Good graphics for the items and the shoppe itself
7. Levelling system for your character,
based off of how much you sell
8. The Music would go in my top 5 List of video game music

CONS__________

1. AI is clunky and has trouble with maneuvering,
which can get you stuck with no way out
2. AI can refuse to accept that some items are free,
and sometimes treat them asthough they are extremely expensive
by trashing the items or ignoring them
3. A little too much dirt left behind by walking NPCs,
not too big of a problem, but a nuissance
4. Barbarians are able to attack through the walls,
meaning that some furniture can be destroyed,
if placed close enough to the wall
5. A little too easy to level up and needs more skills to invest in
6. Has a small amount of bugs scattered around

SUGGESTIONS__________

1. Needs more items and more variety (already has a decent amount,
But once you're rich it gets lame)
2. More skills to invest in and maybe special abilities
3. More of that Sweet Sweet Music
4. Able to Support the Steam workshop
5. Able to customize the size and actual shoppe itself,
E.G the wall colour and shape of the store

All in all this game is very fun and entertaining for me and it manages to do so in a very early state.
I am not a picky guy at all really but I have seen people slander the game with less than 1 hour played
and I just wanted to share my opinion which isnt as harsh as it could be. But do not doubt this game at
all, its got big things and if this game ever goes on sale make sure to pick it up, because its goin' places.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just want to start off saying that I absolutely love this game, I have only played a couple hours but I have fallen in love with it. The price point of $5 just makes it that much sweeter!

Now, let me state my pros and cons of this game for people checking it out.

PROS
------
* Shop keeping!
* The updates coming out for the game look awesome! (Customization, crafting, etc.)
* Nice, simple design, and easy to play.
* Learning curve is easy.
* RPG SYSTEM!!!
* Fun little scenarious and free-play!
* Etc, will probably come back and fill more in.

CONS
-------
* Some minor bugs, however these will be fixed in the future so no worries there.
* No saving mid scenario, so you either finish the scenario or start over if you quit.
* Some issues with the character combat system.
* Etc. (Will fill out more the more I play and the farther along in development this game gets.)

SUGGESTIONS
----------------
* A monster fighting mode.
* Maybe send some customers on missions to get you better and rarer items from dungeoneering and exploring. (Maybe even recipes to make said items to sell.)
* RPG system for combat as well.
* More items! (Of course.)
* SUPER BROOM *Because you know, brooms.*
* Etc. (Will fill out more as game progresses.)

END (Final thoughts)
----
All in all, absolutely wonderful game, and considering there aren't many shopkeeping games around, that just makes this that much more of a gem to me!
9/10
-Orion

reviewText:
SummaryShoppe Keep is a simulation management game. It puts the player in possession of a shoppe, and gives the player the ability to furnish their shoppe with displays / a small selection of decor, and the ability to sell what they want from a huge collection of items.

At this stage, the game is not polished but looks good regardless :: For an indie, built by a three person team, it was very well made and can only continue to get better as updates arrive.

ProsThe game can be addictive as you play due to the upgrade / skill system. As the player unlocks different displays to use, they can continue to organize and setup their shoppe any way they want. The player can sell whatever they want be it weapons, armors, hats / helmets, potions, or a combination of any.
Players will be put against different factors while running their shoppe. These include deteriorating durability on displays which would require repair, dirt accumulation on the shoppe floor, thieves stealing items, barbarian attacks, and more. These are the things that keeps the player focused and actively managing the shoppe, instead of just standing around and waiting for the day to end.
The player is able to customize the way they look and the tools they use while managing the shoppe. Not an important part of the game, but it does add some humor.
Variety to the looks and clothing of customers for added humor.
Seasonal changes for some additional variety to the outside town.
Great musical score that brings life to the game.
NeutralsThe ability to craft new items using recipes is always fun to explore for new players. However, trying to guess at the new recipes can be frustrating, as each incorrect guess will consume all items used. If this feature were to be adjusted to be similar to Minecraft's crafting system (where incorrect guesses will not be consumed) it would work out much better. The saving grace is the recipe book. When a new recipe is found by the player, it is saved in the cauldron's recipe book for quick crafting and is extremely useful.
The visual quality of the game is pretty good considering a three person team. A lot can still be improved upon and it's not the best that it can be, but it's far from the worst I've seen.
The game still has it's selection of bugs, some silly in nature and others possibly game-breaking. Many bugs have yet to be discovered / documented properly. However, with time these bugs can be cleared.
ConsLimited to no ability to mod the game. Many games these days allow for direct community involvement through modding, and some of those games - which are no longer being developed - are only survived by their modding communities. I feel Shoppe Keep would benefit greatly with the ability to be modded easily. It's a big undertaking for a developer to accommodate, but I think it would pay off.
Inconsistent UI. The interface is not well polished, and in need of focused attention. This includes the main menu, in-game menus, the order scroll, champion screen, etc. The main problems are:

Theme - The main menu uses text as buttons and the menus use a transparent background. However, in-game the menu uses text on gradient backgrounds and the menus have a neatly textured background. It's inconsistent.
Ordering / Structure - Commonly, the new game" or "resume game" button should be the very first button on the main menu
date: but in Shoppe Keep it is not. The in-game menu could also use organizing.\nTutorial Tool-tips were rushed. The tutorial tool-tips were a quick way to guide new players into the game
recommended: but were not the best course of action
hoursPlayed: in my opinion. The best solution to this would be to create an entirely new map / world
voteText: and force new players to play that map. It would act as a tutorial map that forces the player to do things in order to learn how to play. Once the player is finished
helpfulPercent: they can start a new game in the "freemode" map
votesHelpful: and do whatever they want like normal.\nConclusionI have been with Shoppe Keep for awhile
votesTotal: played many hours of it

commentsCount: and it's developer really cares about improving the game. In particular
column16: this developer is very active in the Steam Discussions for his game
column17: which is something I appreciate in any developer.\n\nThis game is definitely worth the $10."

reviewText:
Be warned: the music is super catchy.

My six year-old potato runs the game on high settings just fine. There's a slight fps drop during the busiest parts of the day, when a lot of customers are walking around, but it's small enough that I usually don't notice or feel the need to lower my settings.

The UI can be a little clunky and could use more polish, but you get used to it. There is a learning curve at the beginning that can be frustrating (mostly involving the controls). The game would benefit from an interactive tutorial level to ease players into things, in addition to the already present text-based tutorial. I used the wiki a lot during the first few hours of gameplay, which took away some of my early enjoyment.

However, once you figure out the controls and know how to switch between game states this is fun to play. There is plenty to do and future updates will hopefully bring even more content and polish to the game. The devs maintain good communication with the playerbase and appear to be open to suggestions for future updates.

It seems (at a glance) that a lot of the negative reviews only have a couple hours of play time. If I had written my review during the first few hours, it would have been negative too. But again, once you get past the learning curve the game is much more entertaining. I'd recommend new players watch videos of others playing or glance over the wiki before jumping into the game to avoid feeling completely lost.

I did not play this game during early access, so I don't know what the differences are and how the game improved since then, but I do think this is worth the price and don't regret purchasing. If you enjoy tycoon/management games, I definitely recommend giving this game a shot.

reviewText:
Probably one of the first shop games I've played that has been able to tackle the mundane task of sitting behind a till repeating the same thing over and over. With normal shop games you're left sitting there behind a till buying and selling the dearest items you have and thats the game pretty much done. With this game you have the SPACE and the need to supply all items to the customers, if you don't have it on the shelves you're missing out on big money. Plus the game has a morning - day and evening cycle, once you start growing you will learn to prepare for the onslaught of customers and thiefs trying to clear the dirt and bodies while also keeping the shelves stocked and repaired at all times during the day.  The items you sell most one day is almost never the same for the next so you must always keep on track with what the customers want and prepare a stock so the shelves are never empty. The bigger you get the HARDER it gets to keep everything on track and there is alot to work for and hopefully more soon.

bad things about this game is the tutorial is written and some things aren't that obvious. Go to options and increase the size of the hub so you can actually read the texts that helps alot. Then sit through the tedious task of learning through seeing not doing and that alone can be hard for some. I would suggest a help box that appears to explain things while people play so they can play and learn at the same time, its a game not a lesson. And in a perfect world the graphics could be alot better but realistically its not an issue, also if you swing your weapon dont expect to not hit the guy 4 feet away behind the person you are actually aiming for you most likely will, I advise sticking to zaping them. Also getting a new quest will overwrite the one you are on already you can only get a new one if you complete or give up on the old quest.

All in all great concept I hope they touch up on a few things and expand the late game alot more and add alot more difficulty to the game. Other than that the game is well worth the money spent on it and I hope the creators keep expanding on this great idea. Although they have many bugs to work on the difference between this and other indie games is these WILL get fixed, noone will give up on a great idea like this not everyone is that lazy.

Things that I would like to see added over time O:

1. Add citizens to the town and events so you feel like a member of a town
2. House upgrades and furniture so you can customise where you live instead of having it some house you sleep in but don't really
3. Fishing - every game needs fishing especially one where you can sell the fish its a good feeling catching and selling them prize fish and decorating your shop with them
4. Marriage O: it's got to be done also allowing this to upgrade certain things for the house and shop
5. Advertisement - It would be nice to feel the grind of letting the world know your shop exists while you try to control what little money you have also sending adventurers to kill dragons with shop items to make people want that gear
6. Have a shop reviewer come around and rate your shop 1 start to 10 this depends on how clean the shop is, how decorated it is, the use of high tech equipment and other things etc
7. Rats were a problem in history why not make them a real problem here add them to the shops at the start and you have to fight to remove them constantly cleaning and eventually being able to buy rat killers and traps to help control it
8. Add a cost of living to reduce the profit, based on the larger your house is andon who lives there with you meaning you have a goal to increase your profit daily rather than just making more money to buy the dearer things also making the game harder while you try to balance income and expenses which can all go to pot with 1 bad report from an inspector that walks in at the wrong time

That's all for now QQ

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Writing this while it's still in early access.

Right now, the game isn't that well-optimized. It will chug once you get a larger store if you have a crappy laptop with integrated graphics, but it will run fine if you have a regular gaming machine.

The game also isn't balanced yet -- you can get tons of gold without much effort, thought, or risk, although I did have a store wiped out by barbarians once because I wasn't paying attention.

What is good about this game is that there's a solid core to it. What made it click for me was designing a store around the different character classes. You can organize it so that one section you have armor and weapons fo rogues, another for wizards, another for warriors, and so on. That makes it easier to figure out what you need to restock while also making it look more interesting. That aspect is solid right now and will hopefully be built upon. More cosmetics and more gameplay impacts from layout and item sorting would make it more interesting to play.

The other neat thing is that you actually get to see your customers getting equipped as you improve your store stock. They start out looking generic, but they eventually grab whatever the best armor and weapons are for their class. The game does track their names and inventories, but it's kind of finicky to get the interface to show up.

Some caveats are that the game really needs more pressure on the player. Something like a debt mechanic, timed scenarios, more brutal invasions / calamities, more effects of having well-equipped customers, inventory decay, inventory weight, maintenance costs to repair objects, custom difficulty levels, or price fluctuations could improve this a lot. The UI also needs to be improved a lot -- particularly when you're carrying a lot of inventory and crafting something.

I'd recommend this if you're interested in testing it out and the concept sounds fun to you. It's a good simple game to play while listening to podcasts or lectures as it is right now.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very enjoyable so far. It's a mix of tycoon and simulator, and a well done one at that. It's got a warm, friendly 3d environment with lots of space and an open building mechanic. There are some things in the building hinting to future updates, and there is a slight lack of content, but I'm willing to look past it as it's in early access. You buy and place down obects to put your products on, and people come in and buy them. You set the prices and they buy based on them, so if you are trying to sell health potions for 90 gold each, you won't get any sales at all, but if you sell them at 1 or 0, your store will be flooded with people but you will loose money. You also get taxed based on how much you sell, and the more you sell the more specail points you get for upgrades. When people walk in, they leave a dirty trail to wherever they go, which is unappealing to customers. There are lots of little mechanics like that and it makes this game just a little gem. As of now it doesn't have TOO much content but it does have enough for maybe 30 or so hours of entertainment. From the theiving ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that you have to kill, to the arrow in your knee when you look down, I rate this game an 8/10. Also, NO JUMPING.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just a quick impression from the first few hours of EA.  Will try to update my review with each major update to the game.

First impression is that it is exactly what it appears to be:  a management/tycoon game set in first-person.  Controls are tight (though locked for the time being), sights/sounds are great, and the content is plentiful for a just-released Early Access game.

As for the devs, they seem to be quite active at launch:  3 performance/bug updates since launch last week, as well as quite active in the discussion boards should you have any questions/concerns.

Again, VERY quick initial impression, I'll flesh it out as the game is fleshed out.  At the moment, however, $5 is a pretty safe investment if this idea tickles your fancy.

reviewText:
I have been waiting for this game since it first cam to early access. And, while the game could have used a bit more polishing before release, it has alot of content (especially for a 10 dollar game). It starts out very slow, however if you wait out the first few days by selling to people on the streets, you'll have a bustling buisness in no time! The game has its flaws, as mentioned in other reviews, however if you enjoy a casual and relaxed game, you will adore this.

Interesting facts and Tips:
1) The fire, ice and growth potions are seasonal, so in the first ten days, you wont be able to sell ice or growth potions.
2) Scrolling the mouse wheel shows alot of different furniture types (i spent alot of time wondering why i could only use stools)
3) The skills page has multiple tabs (This is how you can increase the items you are able to buy)
4) You can kill good customers so dont shoot a thief with others in the way.
5) You can customize your main charachter in the main menu.
6) The game saves after each day when the doors close (Hitting save shop" will not fully save the game!).

Overall the game is great
hoursPlayed: and quite addictive. You just have to get past the first few days to have fun! Its totally worth the price considering what most games cost nowadays

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking like a great game.

Great graphics, reminds me of Dungeon Defenders. Everything is great so far for an Early Access, not enough content for a full release to keep the player occupied. I still bought it and do not regret it. It's enjoyable.

Things I would suggest:
- Keep the game playing while alt+tabbed. I wanted to browse the web on my second monitor while my shop was gathering customers (upgraded security deals with most of the potential thieves), but apparently when you alt+tab the game pauses. It should be optional whether you want the game paused when unfocused or not.

- Scenarios take ages. I just want to hop in and start a shop through My Shoppe" (free mode) with everything unlocked. I don't want to labor through hours of Scenario mode (similar to campaign mode in other games) just to unlock items for "My Shoppe." My Shoppe should have everything already unlocked.

- A counter where the player can be a cashier rather than running around and having the NPCs automatically pay for items would be great.

- Longer delay for the pop-up messages (top right).

- Game *could* (more of a personal issue rather than a suggestion) use more action by the player. Gather your own wood to sell in the back? Have an actual backyard to plant stuff? Raise cattle by feeding them grain (which you buy) and then slaughtering them in order to sell meat and hide? Things to do while you're waiting for customers to buy stuff or during closing time.

- Closing time would be a great thing to include along with rush hours and everything instead of a forever daylight.

- Signs
recommended: etc.\n\nJust basically look at other shop management games and modify it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never really been into these sorts of games. I like to keep an open mind though, and decided to check this game out after stumbling onto a random YouTube let's play. I bought this game two days ago, and now I'm hooked.

Pros:
Building, planning and expanding your store is fun and intuitive

The mechanics as a whole are very flexible, allowing you to run any sort of shop you could want (keep it small and easy to manage, grow it into a gigantic profit factory, evil company that murders it's customers for crafting materials, etc)

Manages to accurately recreate the retail nightmare of dealing with horrible people that leave your store a disaster area, while still keeping it fun (because now you can murder them)

Closing your shop at the end of the day and giving the player all the time they need to clean up and prepare for the next day is a great way of keeping it from getting too hectic, and allows for a well-deserved breather (seriously, it can get NUTS once your store gets big and popular enough).Cons:
It's a bit unstable right now (I've noticed a weird effect where the game loses more and more stability while the store is open. It's perfectly stable if you've just launched the game and the store is still closed.)
The game is stiill fairly early, and there's plenty of ways the devs could take it. I'd personally like to see more ways to expand your store, more helpers to hire (cleaners, or bots that replace items that customers knock over), and just more content in general. Being able to walk around town, talk to people to see what they want, and even set up advertisements would be great too!

This game is still fun as hell, even in it's current early stage. Solid thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Main Game(Outdated)Warning this is less of a game review than a list of bugs and things that should change.
Shoppe Keep is a tycoon game from the 1st person perspective, you start in a menu that has a awesome title music there are setting(many Early Access games don't have that) also now you can customise your char. by buying the items there and eq. them, the items just buff your speed of doing things and are really cheap after 2 days in My Shoppe mode you can unlock all things (I mean all even the ones you don't need) and still have lots of cash. So back to the title screen there you can go play the tutorial or jump directly in the first scenario where you'll have lots of money a great shop and then get murdered by 100 barbarians, great your shop just got rekt everything is gone, but someone wants to help you out so you get some money and some space for objects, your mission: sell 10 of each potion. after that you'll get put in the 2nd scenario and so on, while playing you'll level up and then you can learn skills that help you in various ways, it will end when you played though all scenarios, but you can go out any time and go to the My Shoppe mode where you can like to name says make your own shop without objectives, you'll start with some money after that you decide what is going to happen, clean, build furniture, buy items, clean, set prices, clean and so on.

There are some things I need to put here because they either bother me or I really like.(aka skip to the end if you don't want idea listing and bugs)

Cleaning: While it's not really bad that it's there later in the game you don't have time to do so because you have so much to do.

Helper Robot: While yes he is helpful against thieves and good at picking items he is not able to Restock, clean and fight barbarians.

Barbarians: They come most often in 3 man packs when you are in the starting time later there will be a boss barbarian and so on, while I like the idea of them they are not as good implemented as they could be. There should be some kind of dungeon defenders vibe going around them with maybe a arena or some pre-shop where you defend your shop against them, that would give them a whole new part in the game.

Furniture: It's good and all that they can be destroyed by the barbarians but why the items!? Items don't destroy your furniture just because you put em on the table. Also the placing needs some better work since you cant put things symmetrical without being a god or something, maybe a grid or something, to that you should be able to move furniture after you place it since I can do that in real life just find I have arms and legs.

Mushrooms: while they are op as ♥♥♥♥, they suck. You plant them and they somehow get stinky when you let them grow for to long but in your inventory they don't age. That makes no sense.

Crowds: you can land between about 20-30 npcs at once and be ♥♥♥♥ed aka. stuck they will keep on moving and so you can't get out. Don't make small corridors.

Price-Setting: It's working like it's right now but you should have a menu where you can see all items and set hte prices, not some + - and shift system that doesn't even remember what item had what %, please change.

RPG-system: It's a great addition to the game, but lacks content.

Saving: In the My Shoppe mode you can't save whenever you want and when you end a day it almost never saves(for me) I played a game got 20k profit in the end of the day and lost all due a bug where I couldnt start the next day (the door stay open bug) meaning I lost the whole day and somehow even more. please fix. I can't play like this lost my whole shoppe mode.

Floor-Mats: Yes they are great no more cleaning but they can be destroyed by barbarians and your sword.

Sword: It feels as if you never hit what you want but you'll always hit furniture breaking it in almost 1 hit so you cant really fight against barbarians because you don't want to break your shi*

Customise: Since now you can customise your char you get better tools but to be hones they are cheap. Very cheap and it feels like they are just there to be there, I really hope it will be updated and also made more expencive since they just feel so cheap and not like something you need to make a clean decision if you want to really spend your money on the tools.

Now some things I would like to see:
-Some way to auto-restock
-A map-editor or modding support
-more potions (expensive)
-more and different shops (having the ability to manage 2 or more shops at the same time)
-a real garden
-the barbarian arena or something like that
-more weapons to use like new magic's swords etc.
-more skills for combat, cleaning etc.
-the price list.
-a Invaders incoming sign or something like that, every npc has magic sense's when they come I want that too.
-Jumping.
-a reason to play the later scenarios, like an achievement or something.
-optimisation. I wont be able to play the game longer than the first few days after that I get 1 fps.
-Money-Balancing, add something that gives the player a reason to have 100k at one time because all the items aren't holding long enough and the profit is to big so you just sell the best items and it takes 5 days to be at the max of everything. give us expencive ♥♥♥♥ for lategame that are worth about 1-20k !
-after bigger shops you don't want to keep yourself to look at the entrance all the time so maybe adding a camara that is placeable or a magic portal connected to your had with a pitboy of sorts would be awesome.

Here comes a Bug-list:-You can kill a barbarian before he gets in your shop causing him to be out of reach for cleaning.
-NPC's can get stuck in a helmet rack causing in after shop modi the doors not to close and the tax time to go on. EDIT: Also causes the game to not go to the next day anymore making it a gamebreaker Please Fix!
-after you exit the game steam doesn't get that you went out of it.EDIT: Only for some people
-npcs get stuck at furniture also causing them not to get out when barbarians are attacking.
-barbarian can't get to the back-room causing the first level to be a barbarian farm level where you can also get the barbarian achievements.
-floor carpets cant be sold and things can be placed over it but where the carpet is nothing can be placed for sale
-In main menu musik plays at the basic volume causes ear aids.
-sometimes you unlock all levels at random. (Intel by a friend)
-Turning off Edge Detection ingame dosen't work
-NPC's sometimes slide across the floor
-NPC's are in the floor with theyr shoes
-You can build in the pillars

In the EndAs much as i would love to say this game is mega awesome I cant because the my shoppe mode is to short and the upgrades to op, when you can set everything on 150% and spam your shelves with stacks of gloves, and tables full of mage robes with armor raks full of lots of 350 armor and a moneystack of 30k+ and nothing to do.
It also does just the same amount of bad as it does good but the idea just keeps it alive, its nowhere near finished and thats good, becausethat means the community has the chance to change it to be one of the greatest tycoon games out there!
Also you get more hours than the price and it's still really cool 9/10 when you consider the price.

Dont judge the game whithout having the one week achivement in My Shoppe or else you didn't see the whole game!

Now that I have written this ♥♥♥♥ twice im finished with it for now. I'll update this whenever there is something I want to add or an update came out. Please give me thumbs up so the developer can read it :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Proudly endorsed by Dave's Reviews For Aging Gamers. Shoppe Keep may be early access, but it's the most interesting casual management sim I've played in a long time. It's a fairly unquie concept, and the designer has a classy sense of humor. Despite a few minor bugs which I'm sure will be resolved long before release, it's a solid game that's well worth the price. As a first generation PC gamer, my golden rule is an hour of play for every dollar spent is a solid gaming investment, and Shoppe Keep delivers.

Bugs aside here's a few cons over-30s should be aware of:
- The wife and I agree: musical score is great, but becomes a bit repetitive. Get your ELO records out.
- The character advancement needs refining, and a lack of speed controls make for long days at the shop.
- Late game is a bit dull at this point in development.
- Personally, I had a bit of difficulty figuring out which items went with which display so it could be sold, but I'm a trial by fire kind of gamer, and dove in head first. A few minutes of reseach could save you this frustration... or it could serve to motivate you like it does me.

Rating: Worthy of my review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep

Shoppe keep is a lovely game to start your own shop and sell the stuff you want.
there are scenarios where you need to sell certain stuff or do certain things.
There is also Freeplay mode ( MyShoppe ) where you can build your own shop and sell your hard earned items, that you earned by completing scenarios.

The game runs very good and haven't had any problems yet.
a few glitches and bugs here and there, but hey, its early access.

The thing i like the most is the way you can make your shop in the freeplay mode. and set prices according to your likeing of the items.
however after certain time you keep doing the same thing and it gets kinda boring. but according to the roadmap this should change through the development of the game. Time will tell.

The scenarios are pretty good. however some scenarios can take up to 3 hours to complete because the customers are not really into buying a certain item and it can take forever to sell.

The game has a lot of potential and i see a bright future for this game.
for now it is really fun to play and you can go through the scenarios and enjoy some freeplay.
its playable and its very stable.

I can recommend this game in its current state.

reviewText:
TLDR: SELL WEED GET DOLLA DOLLA BLING

Started out as a respectable small store offering passerby slightly marked-up low grade equipments. It was a tough beginning but it wasn't hard either -the adventurers seemed to accept most of the things I offered them, maybe because I'm the only merchant in  that part of  the city.

Managed to save some money to sell arms that I ordered from my magical scroll, somewhat similar to a modern day tablet. Business was good until the barbarians decided to visit. Of course the barbarians ignored all the other buildings in the city and every other heavily equipped adventurers, that all feared the barbarians presumably because they run around topless showing their ripped upper torso and also the rad tattoos they had on their faces. I whipped out my sword on my left hand and a magical zapping thunder bolt on my right hand, you know, the standard issue for shopkeepers everywhere. The barbarians started mauling on my display tables and I was busy slashing mice on my shop floor until I realized eventually they're only vulnerable against the mighty broom. Killed the two barbarians and I stood amongst the rubble and mice, pondering of methods to end my life.

I checked my magic scroll/ancient-modern-tablet and swiped left and decided to give farming a try. I spent half of my money to buy mushroom seeds and hoped my luck would change. Alas, it didn't, the mushrooms were harvested a moment too late and were useless, perhaps because preservatives weren't yet invented at that time. In desperation, again I consulted my scroll and spent the remaining of my money... On weed seeds...

I watched closely as they grow, spending no second without them in my sight. As soon as they riped, they were transferred from the garden to the streets. I went from street corners to alleys offering anyone I passed by. The warriors, with their warrior's code and all, doesn't seem to be interested. The more contemporary mages however... Let's just say if they were programmed to buy multiple items of the same type, they'd buy it all.

I bought more seeds to plant which were sold as fast as before, if not faster. I thought to myself maybe this is it..." as I harvested a new batch. Soon enough I could afford a shelf to display my herbs. Soon I had to buy more shelves to display my weeds. Soon I hired robots to display my weeds...

It felt just like yesterday
date: or around 15 minutes in real time that I thought of ending my in-game life after a vicious barbarian attack devastated my shop. Now here I am
recommended: relaxing in the garden behind my (still respectful) weed-shop
hoursPlayed: keeping an eye on my next batch of weed as the cash keeps rolling in."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

it is a very happy medieval fantasy shop management simulator. I have played 7ish hours so far and have loved every minute of it. There are lots and lots of bugs but it is early access. I don't know what the update schedule is like on the game but provided the dev team actively squashes bugs and cleans up some glitchy/annoying interface issues the game will be a solid management game hit.


Edit:
As had been expected there were bugs from the moment I had started playing. Less than seven hours after downloading the game there was an update to fix some glaring issue that I hadn't even gotten far enough to know about yet. As I progressed I found out there were issues with the game that I was having difficulties with. A couple days later, those issues were resolved with a patch.

The development team seems to be actively squashing bugs and interface issues. In addition to that they seem to be interacting with their player base in a positive and constructive way.

My assessment of the game does not ultimately change from my original review of the game. Provided the team says as active as they are currently this is going to be a very solid title and I reccomend it now for anyone who doesn't mind the issues that come with early access, if you do mind early access.... wait until it is complete but still make sure you get the game if you like management style simulators.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely recommend it.

It's a nice game that puts you at actually maintaining a shoppe. It's fantasy related, having you sell potions, swords, and armor for adventurers.

The added touch is that thieves will come steal your merchandise, the added effect of owning a business. You also have the choice of combat, a sword in the left hand, and a spell in the right, deterring thieves who would steal, and killing those who actually took your merchandise.

Good game overall, 8/10. Still in early stages, so I expect a lot of good things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really enjoy playing this game even if there are a lot of bugs and glitches:
- When a customer walks against you, you get teleportet on top of him and you fall down

- When there are a lot of Customers at once, they block each other and they can't get out
- sometimes the safety wall against thieves doesn't trigger and they can simply escape even if the bar on top is green
- Customers kick the items thieves dropped away and the corpses as well. Sometimes that makes the corpse unremovable
- Sometimes the green circle while picking up stuff just stop while picking up

Some suggestions for further Versions:

- How about a real city where you can walk around and buy stuff you can sell in your own shop.
- Diffrent shop styles like a brewerie and a smith and a clothier or something like that.
The smith could buy minerals and create his own weapons and sell them.
The others would do the same with their diffrent products
- Thieves should be rarer but stealthier. You can easily spot them because they try to run pretty obvious

Good things:
- Cute Graphics
- brilliant idea and concept(reminded me of  Dragon Quest: Chapters Of The Chosen Ones)
- simple controls and quick learnable gameplay
- skyrim references
- Banana for scale in the backroom

reviewText:
Early Access Review

QUICK REVIEW:

8.5/10

Developers have their heads straight and there are some minor bugs; perfect for someone who loves simulators! But wouldnt pay more than it is now until there is more content or features.

LONG REVIEW:

I havnt played too much of this game in case i might refund but so far its... different.

Let me start by saying the gameplay is really solid; you take on the role of a shopkeeper, you know those ones that you visit in skyrim and never think about? The ones that could be struggling finacially; or have up to their neck in tax or customers that steal from YOU?!

Anyway you take on the role of this person and you have to manage your shop, deal with theifs and customers that dont put items back where they belong when they are done looking at them. You start with hardly anything and build an empire upwards.

The gameplay is well structured and has a little amount of glitches at the moment; although there have been some glitches like when ive looked outisde my store and noticed NPC's walking through another stores steps and when customers are browing how i seem to hover above them when they walk into me. These are little fixable annoying glitches but can be sorted probably.

The most annoying bug is when customers are browing and seem to get stuck between furniture and display areas; this then ensues that they dont leave and keep moaning the only way to get rid of them is by switching to sword and scaring off everyone in the store.

overall I would say this game is about 8.5/10 for early access thats great! but until more updates are out it still needs more work.

here are the pros and cons in my opinion:

Pros:
- Solid gameplay
- Devs understand where the title is headed
- Simple and sweet graphics
- Not demanding on a low end rig
- easy to understand and play

cons:
- Little annoying bugs
- Customers are too messy
- need more content (there is enough atm but it will definitely need more)

My ideas for improvement:
- Bigger better stores to upgrade to
- being able to walk around the current town and possibly set up branches in different towns/villages/cities
- more diverce AI (clothing, hair, unique people [possible couples that walk in discussing what they like/dislike to add humour])
- possibly different types of store to own and have assistants and employees

reviewText:
This game has been on my wishlist for a while and when it went on sale i jumped on the chance to get it, i grew up on games such as theme park and theme hospital and i love management games in general so these kind of games are engraved into my brain somewhat.

Like another reviewer i was happy when i saw the game was out of early access but it still feels like an early access game its lacking in pretty much everything apart from the basic concept, and that is sell stuff.  Im not complaining as i have put some solid time into this game and plan on continuing as my store is now taking shape, i just wish there were more things in it to make it feel less like a ghost town and more like a thriving town centre.

Customers all look the same both male and female and walk in the same butch manner also there are only about 3 - 4 different expressions on their faces and only 1 hairstyle, the only distingushing feature between male and female are ♥♥♥♥ who has them and who dont oh and names.  There is a market cover out in the courtyard with nothing under it im assuming they put it there for future updates but it would be nice if there was a produce vendor there as you can grow crops so it would give you someone to sell them to and also for the other drones walking aimlessly about to interact with for a moment to make the place feel more alive.

There is no life in game there are no bugs scampering around on the ground no flies and no birds, we have this great big sky with a couple of white lumps stuck in it which i am assuming are clouds and no F"KING BIRDS! i love birds the sky and the world would be so boring without them.  When you stock a variety of items many adventures buy from your store and it can get quite crazy as some customers buy some throw your goods on the ground and others steal so you have to keep an eye out but i find myself even with all this pulse pounding action going on longing for something to happen, there are all these adventurers around so why dont a plague of rats enter the courtyard that they all fight and you can join in aswell and then sell rat hides to crafters and maybe even pilfer your goods back off the bodies of dead adventurers but then it could be more then rats how about seeing a dragon go by in that big empty blue thing at the top of the sky and have that land and start whooping ♥♥♥........ just something..... anything would be nice.

It sounds like im having a right complain but im just pointing out areas that could be improved on and i have really high hopes for this game... i do enjoy it as it is but i wish it was something more and i understand from the main menu there are only 3 people working on this and its all about finding time to do things.  Really looking forward to future updates i just hope they push the boundaries a bit but firstly at least give the guys and gals different hairstyles and walking animations.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sort of a first person Recettear without an annoying little girl trying to scam your items from you at 50% their cost.

It's fun and early game will keep you busy trying to find ways to finish quests and make sure thieves aren't running away with your stuff.  Trying to get the next shop upgrade will keep things hectic for a while.  There's not a lot to do in the late game though.  By then you should have nearly everything except ordering automated giving you time to sell directly to people instead of keeping your shop running smooth, but leaving little else to do besides hope for a barbarian attack so you get a chance at a rare item and sending your champion out.

It's neat to see the villagers eventually come walking by with better and better gear as time goes on, but eventually some day they'll decide that despite paying 1000s of gold for equipment, that 15 gold potion is worth risking their life for and will steal it prompting a lightning blast that ends their life.  It's rare you'll see anyone sporting the full set of any of the higher level equipment because they have so little sense of self preservation.

Alchemy is a great addition too, but unfortunately typically results in you hoarding ingredients until a quest comes along that you can use them for.  Some ingredients don't have a reliable method of getting a large amount of (Such as gold vials/bars).  As such you're unlikely to be able to stock gold armor as a shop item reliably.  Though you can get mihr needed for the enchanted items fairly simply through mana potions.

The game is fairly solid otherwise but needs a bit more to keep you playing.  New shop locations/items/milestones would go a long way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I accidentally stayed up all night playing despite all of the glitches and quirks that come with this game being Early Access, so I guess I recommend it!
None of the issues were game-breaking, at least for me, so if you can deal with some weird physics and occasional inconveniences, it's a lot of fun!

Some things I'd like to see changed in the near future:
- Dirt- No one is that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dirty. Sweeping should have to be done often when you have a lot of customers, but there's no reason you should have to walk behind someone constantly sweeping like some sort of reverse olympic curler.
- Build Mode - Make it so that you can move furniture you've already placed. In real life you don't sell your $250 shelf for $3 and re-buy the exact same shelf just because you put it in the wrong spot in your house.
- Prices - An easier way to adjust prices, so that you don't have to pick up 30 potions and put them back down just to change the price from 2g to 3g.
- Ordering in bulk - instead of clicking on a potion 50 times to order 50, a little quantity box would be great.
- Perhaps a way to adjust your security forcefield? If I'm making bank, I really don't mind if one guy steals a 2g profit potion every once in a while. If the gate only stopped them if they were trying to get away with an item that would net a certain amount of profit (that you set), I think that would be nice.
- Some female NPCs? Its really kind of eerie that I get hundreds of customers every day but not a single one is female.
- And of course, a way to customise your shop; decorations, different color schemes and furniture types, wallpaper/paint, flooring, etc.
