reviewText:
Early Access Review

my review of this game is gonna be what i experienced and will continue experiencing as i play through

tl;dr version
i sold a armor to a warrior then killed him and sold it again at a discounted rate

long version
this game is currently in early access but it has a lot of scenarios to do (around 20 or so) each taking 20mins to an hour to complete

scenarios start off slow as it starts you with almost no gold, you probally will be selling potions for 1 gold profit for 5-10 minutes which really sucks then they pick up and you have a lot of chores to do

the chore features are;

SWEEPING to keep your shop appeal clean (scenarios also have a minimum shop appeal requirement that gets inspected every 5 minutes so you have to sweep a lot) this is one of the things you will be doing the most as no one wipes their feet before entering your shop

REPAIRING your stands as they get damaged as the customers seemingly just peek at items

RESTOCKING your shelves in realtime while KILLING thieves that try to steal your merchandise (at first this is hard as they are fast but you adapt (there are traits) that help you deal with them)

apart from the genericness that it sounds this game is really fast paced once you get past the potions customers eventually come in by the dozens and you end up trying to catch 2-3 thieves at once causing mass panic in your shop

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a GREAT GAME. However it is still early access so there will be bugs, Ive counted three, but nothing game breaking  The bugs aside the game has shown great potential to grow. It runs very smoothly no my computer which is not beefy. upgrades help out alot, but not enough to make the game op and broken which is good. When you get a couple upgrades  the game gets really fun. The more you sell the more you have to pay attention to things like thieves(bad) and mushrooms (good). You cant simply walk away from the game and expect to make a bunch of money because all your items will sell/be stolen. There is nothing in the game that allows you to automate the selling of items which is good and keeps the game going. You also have to clean your store and protect it from bandits who only come in to destroy your shelves and what not. Its a fun game get it reguardless of sale or not its totally worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I accidentally stayed up all night playing despite all of the glitches and quirks that come with this game being Early Access, so I guess I recommend it!
None of the issues were game-breaking, at least for me, so if you can deal with some weird physics and occasional inconveniences, it's a lot of fun!

Some things I'd like to see changed in the near future:
- Dirt- No one is that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dirty. Sweeping should have to be done often when you have a lot of customers, but there's no reason you should have to walk behind someone constantly sweeping like some sort of reverse olympic curler.
- Build Mode - Make it so that you can move furniture you've already placed. In real life you don't sell your $250 shelf for $3 and re-buy the exact same shelf just because you put it in the wrong spot in your house.
- Prices - An easier way to adjust prices, so that you don't have to pick up 30 potions and put them back down just to change the price from 2g to 3g.
- Ordering in bulk - instead of clicking on a potion 50 times to order 50, a little quantity box would be great.
- Perhaps a way to adjust your security forcefield? If I'm making bank, I really don't mind if one guy steals a 2g profit potion every once in a while. If the gate only stopped them if they were trying to get away with an item that would net a certain amount of profit (that you set), I think that would be nice.
- Some female NPCs? Its really kind of eerie that I get hundreds of customers every day but not a single one is female.
- And of course, a way to customise your shop; decorations, different color schemes and furniture types, wallpaper/paint, flooring, etc.

Ladies and gentlemen. I ask you please to rest your but and listen as I tell you about this wondrous game!!! Not only is this a game where you own and manage a shop. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: Now, This game is in early access and I believe there possibly going to more things included in the future, so I may update my review further once development of the game is nearly complete.

This Game... I mean it seems to be good, the concept seems rather nice. The main purpose of the game is to manage store in an fantasy world, an RPG one in fact to where you offer items to commoners and heroes. Though It doesn't sound that hard of a job to do such an thing unless the heroes go and act like the kind of heroes that players tend to be, those kind to which mess everything up for fun or even steal something out of plain view. You will feel the pain of an typical RPG Shop clerk, having to reorganize your wares, keeping an close eye on your customers, and also have to beware of barbarians who occasionally pay you an visit to ransack your store. Yet, I know I make all of this sound like something that could be an pain, but it's actually quite fun in my opinion.

As you progress through the scenarios in the game, you get level ups that allow you get bonus things that will help you out along the way and may unlock things from the missions. Also from the start of the game, you have in your possession an sword and an lightning spell that allows you to humorously take care of your thieving heroes and bloodthirsty barbarians, all while you are protecting your wares. The combat" seems quite good and easy

reviewText:
I honestly never heard of this game until it's full release like a day ago. I'm not usually one to jump on games (especially on steam unless it's the summer sale) but I figured hey it's on sale, why not?

Gameplay is simple enough: you have a shop, you order items, you decide how much markup you're selling them for, you fill your shop with displays and decorations. you dig enchanted swords out of the trashcans - along the way you enjoy a joke or two and try to jump. The low-poly graphics aren't up everyone's alley but it's style is a breath of fresh air (at least for me).

I'm...I'm honestly not sure why I love it so much. The graphics aren't amazing, the UI still needs some work, there's room for more development surely but...there's something about this game that just makes me smile. Is it the goofy townfolk with names like Bertha Buttface the Rogue"? Is it the happy
date: heel-clicking music? Is it the rush I get from nuking theives and then sweeping away their bones because you gotta keep a clean shop? I don't know. I think this game gives me a good nostalgia vibe of the old PC games I played in middle school.\n\nI recommend this game BUT I think it's audience is...very much a niche market right now. The game needs some polish still but I would certainly say it's worth a buy when it's on sale. And PLEASE get the soundtrack with it - you will not be disappointed!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Check out my hour long first-play & review video for my thoughts and opinions as I play this early access game on launch day here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sJKFKO9e-hs

This game offers a very unique style of gameplay that I've never quite seen or played in all my years of gaming.  While I've played the RPG warrior or mage needing to shop for supples and potions more times then I can count, I've never seen the perspective from the shop keeper trying to earn a little chunk of the advenrturers treasures.

This game offers almost twenty quests" as you would call them as they are simply goals that start out easy and progressively get harder.  Each one will tell you the goal such as sell 10 of each type of potion or earn 5000 gold as well as other requirements needed to pass it such as paying taxes every 5 minutes and keeping your shop appeal at a certain level on inspections.

To make a profit
date: you must order your goods from a list by simply going into shop-keep mode
recommended: then hitting your Q button to bring up a list of supplies to order from.  Once an order is placed
hoursPlayed: you can then place your items on any of your available tables and racks for display but be sure to change your profit margin as it it set to 100% by default which means you will sell it for exactly what you paid for it!  You can hold down your shift key while pressing the + and - keys to change this rate faster and once you set it
voteText: it will stay there for that entire level unless you change it again.  You can also charge a different rate for a specific item or items by changing your rate before placing that item(s) and then changing it back.  It's all much easier then I can make it sound here in words.\n\nThe wizards and warriors who come into your shop will bring in tons of dirt and grime which will quickly dirty your floor and lower your shop appeal.  Lower shop appeal equals less customers and could prevent you from passing a specific level as well
helpfulPercent: so go to your broom mode on the riht side of your screen and simply left click around the dirt to instantly clean up the mess
votesHelpful: and be sure you do this frequently!  Thankfully
votesTotal: atleast for me
votesFunny: sweeping the floor never seemed like a chore or like an annoyance
commentsCount: and in fact it seemed to add to the overal challenge and enjoyment I experienced.  It's hard to describe
column16: but it just works well with this game!\n\nAs a shop keeper
column17: you'll also have to deal with the common thieves that will frequently try and steal your goods
column18: robbing you of the potential income those items could earn you!  You can go into fight mode and slash a sword at them or blast them with an electric charge

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still in Early Access, but so far I'm very impressed.  The developers are taking the time to get the basic game right before adding more things into it, and are doing a fantastic job at it.  The game itself is easy to pick up and fun to play.  There isn't any end game content yet, but that's on it's way.

Dev's have stated that they want the game to be right and also be want the community wants.  They're listening to the player base!

I've enjoyed playing the game so far, even the bugs don't ruin the experience and they're disappearing as fast as we can find and report them.

Definitely give this one a go, it's seriously under priced, even for early access, these guys deserve more just for the low price tag!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My god this game has come so far since I first played it.

It was pretty slow when I started it back up. But now that I've got my shop up and running, basically filled out the starting room with, fully stocked with some spare change... This game is insanely addicting.

The game has a really good shop management thing going on. I absolutely love games like this but I dont see many well executed ones. You feel like you've really built something once you get going. But this game goes a little bit further than just running a shop. NPCs will return to your shop again after they've been there before. You get to see all the adventurers grow. At first people only have their clothes, eventually they'll be fully suited in armor and weapons.

Some guy comes in my shop and knocks a few potions off my shelf, I follow him around town and flick him off until he leaves. Most of my rare goods are things I found in trash cans. I've got 2-3 adventurers that i've decked out with some rare gear that I buy nice stuff from when they stop by. I've murdered 5 guys that look like someone on a wanted poster I found, still not the right guy. When I'm broke, I dont feel bad about shooting lightning bolts in the faces of people that call me a peasant and throw the boots I just picked up off the floor, back on the floor. The streets are littered with skeletons of the thieves I've killed, just out of range of my shop so everyone doesnt get scared and run away.

There's so much about this game that I just love.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The gameplay is a fresh and fun take on tried and true tycoon elements combined with action elements creating a tasteful simplicity that could easlily be expanded upon in future updates. The soundtrack is enjoyable.

The basic dynamic is that as the store becomes more successful/popular the more demanding the store cleaning  and thief defending becomes challenging the gamer to balance cleaning, thief defence and inventory management.

At time of writing this game is not as polished as other Early Access games that I've played (Starbound, 7 days to die, etc). It's very glitchy and it is virtually impossible to kill thieves because the screen gets crammed with customers and you always kill innocents and get penalized for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
Let me start by saying that this game is MOST DEFINITELY worth the money. Currently, it's $7, but I would happily pay $10 of $15 for it.
I saw the game on a YouTube channel, bought it, and accidentally played it for several hours! At first, I was hesitant to purchase it because I didn't know if it would function on my laptop, which has integrated Intel graphics. This game works BEAUTIFULLY, even with my pitiful PC specs and my integrated graphics.

Cons:
Secondly, the dirt that customers drag in gets to be a lot. During the day, restocking is almost impossible whilst trying to keep my floors clean! Turn down the amount of dirt, please!

REVISED:
The recent update of this game has added a save feature. Bless you, sir.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying this is my first review, and everything expressed in this review is a matter of personal taste.

The game is fun. Living the life of a Shoppe Keeper is a cathartic experience that's nice to wind down after a hard day at work. What really appeals to me is you're not forced to kill enough people per level/day to be classified as a medium sized natural disaster, but you can if you want. There's no rule to say you can't murder all your paying customers as well as thieves. There's a tax placed on you for murdering innocents, but honestly it's so small that ocasionally I started zapping people for giggles.

Buying shelves and placing them is fairly simple, ordering items is also simple. It'd be nice to have a snapping feature so I can place tables and shelves and such end to end with no gaps and agenst the walls. But what I have to say is my favorit thing about this early access release is how much effort the devs are putting in to listening to the players.

For instance, my two personal peeves in the game were how you had to remove every item from a shelf in order to reprice them, and how customers seem to be mudmen from the plannet swampzilla for the amount of dirt they track in. In a quickly implimented patch, door mats were introduced, which stop customers from tracking in dirt, and it was made so that changing the price of one item changes the ones already placed as well. These are supposidly only temporary fixes with improvments comming as development continues. This shows that the devs are listening and they want this game to be fun.

However, the game is not perfect. It's early access, so there's bugs, missing features, and some things that are just kind of obnoxious at present. The tax system for instance seems to be there only to soak up some of your money. There are no guards, no improvments made to the outside town over time ect. I guess the mayor of the town just sleeps on a bed made of solid gold in his mansion made of solid gold or something. It's also a bit to easy to accidently incinerate an innocent with your zap spell because it has a large hit box, but as someone who kills the civies for giggles that's not really a big deal to me personaly. There's also an upgrade that makes it so you can't kill innocents, which I've ignored because every now and then i want to be the evil shop master of the demon realm.

This game is well worth the price of entry, and if you're looking for something origional and fun it's right here. I truly look forward to this games future and hope that the devs can take this game from good to great. It has real potential to a powerhouse of time wasting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't listen to those haters out there who don't have the patience in games in the working. This game is a very fun and addictive game to play, you just have to give it some time to develop and put in the time to actually play the game. The game runs very smoothly and has great graphics. I could play it for hours and hours. The only bad things are the taxes, completing a mission yet, it still thinks you haven't completed it, killing innocent people on accident instead of robbers, (but in the game you can upgrade your guy and one of them is not zapping an innocent person ever again) the tutorial needs some working on and should actually show how to do those things because I still haven't figured out how to build  tables and get plants, and OMG, THE REPAIR REPAIR REPAIR TAKES FOREVER!

Overall: This game has great potential and I can't wait to see how it grows, but it can't grow with you getting the game, so get it to help the developers develop the game more. There are way more pros than cons in this game, and I didn't feel like listing all the pros. And remember, THIS GAME IS DEVELOPING AND IT ISN'T QUITE PERFECT SO DON'T GIVE UP ON IT, BECAUSE IT WILL GET BETTER. IT IS DEVELOPING.

P.S. This game is a GREAT STEAL! it is only for 4.99! how many great games can you get this good in development for only 4.99? most games in development cost way more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is a fun little game where instead of you being the adventurer, you are instead the vendor that sells them items. You are able to decide what you sell and their prices. There are 3 skill trees you can pick and choose from to evolve your shop. There is always the chances of thieves stealing your items to being raided by barbanians to keep you on your toes. I love the cartoony style of the game aswell, and the developers are always open to feedback.
But there are some problems however. NPCs track way too much dirt into the store, making me clean over and over, but I guess that gives me something to do while people are shopping. Scenarios take a bit of time [30 mins average for me], and you need those to unlock items for My Shoppe mode, which I don't really have a problem with other than the fact that some items almost never get sold, and some of those are items are items that NEED to be sold, drastically adding time it takes to complete the scenario. Even worse is the fact that Scenarios have no save button, meaning that if I have to go or something in the middle of a scenario I've spent a long time on, I'd have to restart the scenario if I close the game. I hope one gets implemented soon.
But that's where my complaints end. I've seen a few graphical glitches, such as NPCs going through stairs, but nothing gamebreaking. Overall, the game is very enjoyable and I would reccomend it. Plus it's only 5 dollars!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review for an early access game. I won't normally review until I see the final completed product, but this is an exception. The reason for this being is, that even though this game is early access, it's still playable and at this early stage could almost be passed off as a full game.

Shoppe Keep is a fun, addictive shop management game where you can literally spend hours building, stocking, decorating and re-arranging your shop.

The developer is extremely active, often releasing small patches every couple of days, tweaking game mechanics, and adding more exciting features.

Also, this game is just £5! It's an absolute steal!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever want to play as the owner of a small shop which sells items of minor destruction?  Have you ever wanted to see the happy faces of customers only to respond with words of complete awe when you have a 10,000% mark-up on the most worthless item in your shop?  Have you ever wanted to see how many customers you could kill but still remain with a reputation high enough to allow more customers to come buy your wares?

Shoppe Keep is a great little game with an active devlopment process.  Tons of bugs, sometimes pretty funny and game breaking, but a true Alpha title, with fixes in the works.  This title keeps you pretty busy, from sweeping the floors, to purchasing / placing your items, it always feels like I'm running back and forth trying to keep up with the supply and demand... and the demand always seems to be winning!

For being Alpha and having active dev's, I cannot bad-mouth this title one bit.  It works as advertised and so far, from the updates I have seen, they always manage to tackle the big problems and add cool new little things.  Cannot wait to see this game once it gets to the point of Beta/Release.  I think it'll be something special.

BTW, can we have CO-OP multiplayer?  I'd like to run around placing items while someone sits at the door slaughtering the thieves!  Well, maybe not, but still, the game has a nice price-point for what it offers, and plays well for the state of the game.  No complaints, great job thus far!

reviewText:
Shoppe Keep as a game is fun to play and has a unique style. If you want to enjoy a handful of hours re-arranging and designing a shop then it's a decent game to try. Later game stock you can unlock takes a lot of time to organize if you want to show all the items. Lots of gameplay is spent sorting it's display furniture (or remaking it after a brawl of barbarians). Anti-theft is something one benefits from as soon as they can afford it and is the only thing I use the robots for.

If you like collecting achievements and use them as goals to give the game more direction, then I don't recommend this. With both pre-release and the final product I've had to restart thrice to earn achievements I've already accomplished. As someone who gets excited to have even a small amount of completed games, it's discouraging to know that players will never get 100% due to glitches and creator only icons.

Overall I found it fun but lost the urge of replaying it now that it's out. One of the downfalls of longer running early access titles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once upon a time, you were an adventurer. You traveled the lands slaying dragons, exploring caves, and hunting down bandits. You were the best. You could chop a dragons head off in one swing. However, then tragedy struck. You were hunting bandits down, an average tuesday for you, and easily cleared the camp. But one bandit hid, and after you sheathed your weapons, shot an arrow. It hit you in the knee.

The doctors saved you, however, they were unable to remove the arrow. You were never able to jump again. Or adventure.

You didnt know what to do with your life. You had a sizeable sum of money left over from your adventuring days, but you didnt know what to spend it on. However, you heard a rumor of a famous shop. Apparently, the owner was killed in a barbarian raid, and his wife decided to sell the shop. You bought it. It cost every single gold you have saved up, save for a small amount: 60 pieces. Can you build a shop up from the ground with only 60 gold?

That is what Shoppe Keep is all about. It is an amazing game, even while in early access, and it will only get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is a truly fun, truly unique game.  Although when first starting the game it seems very slow, the game quickly expands, allowing you to design a small shop however you want.  The game excels at giving the player freedom to purchase their own furniture as well as goods, before allowing you to sell them at whatever profit you want.

The game can feel at times like one big grind, especially when you spend day after day simply selling goods and raising money.  However, the unlock system and wide range of goods available make this grind feel worthwhile.  It is a great feeling to see your shop progress over time and become more and more successful.

The developers of the game clearly care a lot about this game, which is evident by the many new features as well as fixes which are frequently added.

Pros:
- Great shop customisability
- Rewarding to see shop progress
- Lots of new features frequently added
- Fun and relaxed gameplay

Cons:
- Basically one big grind
- Very slow start
- Occasional visual bugs

reviewText: This is one of the most addicting games ever!!!! It does start off a little slow however, the first hour I was not sure if I wanted a refund but then I started playing it, and it did start to shine about the 2nd hour. I had finally made enough money to buy a stand and some expensive item such as a shield, then my income just started going through the roof. All of a sudden there were plenty of thieves trying to steal my goods and once I was done killing the thieves people had bought all the items in my store so I had to restock. This is a very hectic game once you get into it. The sound track is also on par with Zelda music, I actually enjoy the music in the game. There are some bugs however that I haven't really cared to worry about. However there are some things I think would be cool.\nI think this game would be great if the combat was worked a little to be more smoothe, and introduce different weapons for the shop keeper and add a different kind of store, a caravan. I think if we could have a caravan and travel around the land and see more than just the one boring town. The caravan would have to multiplayer of course, can't hae a lone shopkeeper wandering around the land now can we?
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me tell you how much I wanted this game. I sold all of my CSGO skins for this game. Yes, I did. No lie.

Let me tell you also, it was very much worth it. Not many hours into this game, but I can see that there will be. I am very excited to get my shoppe full of annoying customers and those stealers! I got a sword, brah I ain't afraid to use it on you.

It starts off a bit slow because, your awaiting for customers. I had to restart my shop because I messed up and didn't get enough profit at the start and couldn't afford to buy things etc. So make sure you make enough profit at the start to build up! Highly recommended.

This type of game is what I like to buy on steam, the games I actually enjoy. It actually teaches you how to handle money and how to earn money too, which is great considering my family own a business, so now I can say I have business experience ;)

Also, love what the J key does in game ;)

Oh and I sold some stuff to a guy named Justin Bieber.... lol what.

reviewText:
I did not think that I would like this game, but now find myself putting in over 8 hours already.  Those who claim that the start is slow, are just being lazy.  You do not have to wait for people to buy your goods, you can leave your shop and sell to them directly.  This is a great way to fly through quests for more unlocks.  It didn't take me long at all.

My only complaint is that the UI is a bit clucky and the tutorial (or lack there of) sucks.

For only $10 though, you get a lot of entertainment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game first appealed to me with when I seen the style of the graphics and the management style gameplay. Even though it is in Early Access the game still has many hours of fun in it. I didn't notice many issues with this early access build, although the two biggest and most annoying issues was the camera and collision with NPC's. The camera movement isn't exactly smooth and is actually rather jittery which made me a lil' dizzy every so often although it was still playable.

The second issue was the collision with NPC's. I would be stocking up shelves and an NPC would walk into me resulting on me lifting up into the air and standing ontop of them which disrupted me from stocking my shelves and can prove as an annoyance if your shop is busy.

Apart from that the game is great and I can see potention in this if the developers listen to the feedback given from their players and shape a game worth releasing!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was supplied with this key by the developer, this however did not affect the review. All my developer sponsored reviews are positive because I review games that I like!═══════════════════════════════════OVERVIEW
Shoppe Keep is a first-person shop managing game where you, instead of going on an adventure to slay mighty beasts, run a shoppe that supplies mighty warriors, mages and other classes for their own adventure. In the beginning you might find yourself confused on what and how to do certain things which is why game includes a tutorial book rather than a tutorial level that you can access any time while in-game. The game is in Early Access which does mean that you will encounter either unfinished or broken features but, that won't be a problem once its fully out of development. The game gets updated few times each month and developers[i.imgur.com] post frequent announcements about upcoming updates while they still listen to the community. Its your shop - your rules; you can place the objects and set the prices however you want to. Area outside the shop is explorable but be careful, you might get stuck and since you can't jump you are stuck there forever; one more thing that I didn't like about that area is that you can see NPCs appearing out of nowhere. Anyway, the game is ready to be played with few visual and gameplay bugs which will of course get fixed soon, I recommend getting it you will surely have fun with it.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/381120
═══════════════════════════════════PROS & CONS
Pros:Thieves and Barbarians | Each day thieves will try to steal and barbarians will try to raid your shop. You must take them out while watching out at other customers.
Tutorial Book | You have problems understanding few things if you are new, thankfully there is some kind of tutorial book which you can access in-game and on the main menu and it explains a lot of things to the depth.
Building you own shop | You are able to place objects however you wish.
Class based customers | Each NPC will be assigned a class like warrior or mage and they will have their own weapon preferenceCons:FPS drops after shop becomes crowded | Once your shop gets all popular you will get FPS drops.
No Jumping | I don't know if this was planned to be added later or if it wasn't planned to be added at all but jumping seems like this game really needs it, you are glued to the ground.
NPCs appear and disappear | When you open your shop and go to one of the spawnpoints for NPCs you can see them appearing and disappearing out of nowhere
Terrain and objects don't have right collisions | In few places you can go few pixels into the texture═══════════════════════════════════SUMMARY & FINAL RATING
This game is for everyone that likes management games that still keep some action mechanics. I rate the game 8/10, would get raided in the middle of town again! Early Access Warning: Game is unfinished but still worth the price.

═══════════════════════════════════For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIve only played for a few hours but i still wanted to write a small review.  This game in my opinion is pretty good for what it is.  Its exactly what the title says shoppe keep.  You basically run a General type store stocking items for the common adventurer.  Everything from potions to swords and shields.  This game lets you do everything a shop keeper would be expected to do.  You can price items however you wish, order more of everything, and set up the shop however you see fit to have a unique shop.  There are extras to you can send a adventure to adventure for more items and you can even defend your shop from thiefs and bandits trying to ran sack your shop.  The game still needs more items and more to do but the creators of the game do updates all the time so its a small complaint.  If you just want to play being a shop keeper for the common adventurer this games for you.

reviewText:
Overall about a 4/5, it seems like a work in progress but with really great potential.
I’m a couple hours into it, and it seems like a great game.  Fresh gameplay created by playing the NPC in a traditional RPG.  The mechanics make for an interesting and diverse set of challenges.  It is not a 40-hour game; but I was dying for something that was not a clone of everything else, and this fits the bill.
Note: I was writing a review that was, in summary great game but with such an awful introductory phase that made it almost unplayable; however, while I was writing the review the game was updated, and all of the major issues were fixed.

reviewText:
I purchased this game in Early Access, I didn't play much then, but I can say there has been TONS of changes since. I'm going to keep this short cause I dont want to write much. So have a Pro/Cons list.

ProsChallenging after about 10 days ingame
Great music at each time of day
Leveling + Perks
Cartoon graphics, this might not be a good thing for the HARDCORE GRAPHICS people
Other things I cant think about as of writing this
ConsTutorial, but once you know its easy
UI a little bare, probaly will improve
Price changing; you set it to a % increase, but you have to change it for other items for example: Sword = 150%, but then you want your Boots to be set lower, so you have to change it. Then someone knocks your Sword off, then you have to pick it up and put your price back up to 150%, and so on. It gets to a point were you just keep everything at one %, only thing that would need to be done is make each item have thier own price mark up, so this isn't a problem.
Overall?
8/10, minor fixes, but still worth the money.

Well I guess I lied about not writing much.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting for a game like this to come around for some time now. We've all played the epic style rpg game fighting dragons and undead, but most of us can agree that while playing those we've all wish man I'd just like to be a shopkeeper in a world like this. Well now you can. So far the game has been very entertaining. Love the art style and the simplistic gameplay. So here are my pros and cons for the game so far:

Pros:
1. Great price for an early access game
2. The free play mode for your very own shop
3. Zapping those pesky thieves and barbarians
4. Running the shop keeps you constantly busy
5. Doesn’t take itself too seriously which leads to some very hilarious moments

Cons:
1. Taxation without representation (pay taxes for no services in return)
2. Glitchy doorway so makes it pain to chase thieves

Another thing I’d like to add which isn’t a con but I’d like to see in the game is a form of multiplayer, where you have a bigger shop with more customers to manage and more area to stock items. Other than that, great game at a low price so I definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING:  This game will suck the life out of you.

The polish on the helper bots was the final bit that has made this game extremely manageable.  There are very few bugs within the game itself.  What bugs do exist are typically have work arounds in place, or are very manageable.  I would highly recommend this game now.  It is definitely worth the price, and compared to other early access games, it could be seen as a full release.

If you enjoy economic simulators with a feel of extremely nostalgic RPG elements, you will love this game.

reviewText:
opening statement:all i can say about shoppe keep is this.it certainly has potential to rival minecraft.

i would like to say the pros and cons ive found in this game
pros-
FREAKING ADDICTIVE.ive played for a whole 24 hrs just enjoying the game.

although blocky like minecraft would be as far as character models go,the animations of them walking and running are almost completely seemless with the very rare glitch of their limbs flying around on screen.this is aceptable to some but the devs may wanna double check it to be sure it dosent cause a major issue.too many good games went out like that.

the music is calm and relaxing and is definately a treat when playing the game to relax.

the ability to kill theives....my biggest pet peeve is theives who steal for fun and not survival.i sometimes let em go if they got a potion,anything else and they die. >:)

now here are the things i feel that we as the community want.

MULTIPLAYER [nuff said]
less customers throwing stuff around,or if possible the ability to kill them and not have a fine slapped on you.if that dosent work we want an animation where the cutomers actually throw stuff around or randomly place items down in areas of the store that dont make any sence. like for example a potion in the middle of ninjas stars.

cons
the fact that the experiance leveling is taking too long to level up to unlock the skill trees is a bit of a bother to me.id like to try to experiance a means to actually level quickly.

having a hero to go on quests is fun,but the thing that upsets me is the fact that he DOSENT CHASE THEIVES DOWN OR HELP DEFEND THE SHOP. please change this asap!

helper bots are awsome but it would not fullfill the experiance of being a shop keeper without actually HIRING underlings to work for you in certain areas. like for example one hired hand could clean the store consitaintly as a maid for say 100 gold a day.or as another example whilst the helper bots collect items a store clerk can help the player by restocking according to what the player has certain items on.[like potions with potions ect]and if they mess up epically you can fire them...or kill them whichever ya preferr.

the graphics are ok but need a slight tune up.from far away i can still see lines formed around people who walk around in the distaince.please try to tweak this to give a better streamlined experiance.

as many have tried we WANNA JUMP DAMNIT haha.

there should be a creative" mode where you have a fully unlocked shop  with hero to where ya can build with a max of at least 50
date: 000 coins. WHY OH WHY HASNT THIS HAPPEND?\n\nclosing statement-i love this game
recommended: i want it to be multiplayer so bad
hoursPlayed: it needs a few tweaks before it can really sell a golden award to the fans.but dont mistake it for an underdog.this has simulation game of the year written on it provided the devs can make the time and effort to give the masses what they need for their quest in making epic loot.\n\nbest regards
voteText: \npalagriz\nhard hitting gaming critic"

reviewText:
So I've been waiting for this game to come out for a while. Love it.

Pros:
Graphics are funny and quirky.  To begin with start by selling to customers outside the shop to earn a couple extra coins, then work your way up. Like the fact that you get your money back from removing the furniture. Love the fact that there is a back room, just wish you could decorate it more.

Cons:
Ui is eh, only need to put the instructions in the menu rather then just the main menu. Don't like clipping through the doors. I hate the factor that they can walk in between counters, makes catching thieves extremely hard. Also don't like that the thieves run in a straight line to the exit, rather then create a chase through the alley ways to the exit. When a customer doesn't buy something and drops it to the floor you can't pick it up sometimes(sometimes!!).

reviewText:
When I first started I was put off by the graphics. But ok since the gameplay is good I  dont mind them as long as the game runs smoothly...well after reaching level 10, it doesnt run smoothly anymore. It became nearly unplayable on lowest setting (was running on high with no problems at the start).
If I could ask for a refund after 4 hours of playtime I would.

Pros: Enjoyable gameplay, very fun when you get the hang of it.
Cons: FPS drops to nearly 0 after accumulating more items

Edit: The developer is working with me on trying to resolve the issue.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is a lot of fun, however, I have a few issues with it in its current state.  The most notable is that I get sick playing with it.  The only other game I have had this issue with is Minecraft.  For what ever reason, I cannot play longer than 30 minute intervals without getting nautious.  I think it has to do with the camera movement or graphics, but Im not entirely sure what does it.  Another, more easily fixable issue I have found is that the game is still quite buggy.  Some items that fall on the ground seem to have to be kicked around a few times before the game will let me pick them up.  A very irritating bug is that when trying to put items on shelves,  it seems like every now and then, the bottom corner spots I am unable to place items in.  Makes things very Irritating when trying to start my day with the shelves full..  At first I thought this was due to a shelf being placed too close to a wall or corner, but have found that it happens even to shelves placed in the middle of the floor with nothing surrounding them..  Like I said,  I have had a lot of fun so far playing the game.  Adding the ability to walk around the city and sell to people who arent headed to your store is cool.  The skills and items you can purchase seem well thought out and allow for different aproaches to starting out your shop.  There are a lot of very cool concepts going on in this game.  I look forward to seeing how they flesh the game out down the road.

reviewText:
I've had this game on my wishlist for a while and bought it when it came out of early access.

Firstly, I would like to say that other reviewers are right in saying that the tutorial only being readable causes some problems - I got stuck at the start trying to retrieve ordered goods and then ended up buying a seasonal good that no one would buy which slowed me down a bit. That having been said, however, I actually do like this game.

I think that it would be a mistake to compare this game to Recettear and other business sims because they are different styles of game. Recettear is a strategic money making game where the pressure is on making enough money to pay the bills; in comparison this game puts the pressure on managing the actual shop floor in real time - theres a good reason its called shop keepe - and there is pressure in that you have to work out on the fly what to buy more of and what not to; it's fun but think that the lack of actual consequences for doing a bad job may be detrimental to my future experience.

The biggest thing to prepare yourself for if you are thinking about getting the game is the slow start. You start with low money and nothing unlocked as expected and that means low customers and thus not much to actually do. Luckily this can be alleviated by going and selling items to people in the street but it is nonetheless initially repetitive in a boring manner. It does get better!

By far the biggest issue is the tutorial for this game and I really hope that the developers change it so that its an ingame as-it-happens tutorial rather than a text one. This could be done in a way that makes the keybinding clearer too -  like the shifts for the price changes.

Overall as long as you are prepared to play a game about being a shop keeper and not just a business simulation I think you'll enjoy it.

UPDATE: Having played another 6 hours I can safely say that my concerns about future gameplay have been assuaged; once you get going the game gets pretty frantic. The devs continue to update at a steady pace atm with an update done today so I'm hopeful that the UI and tutorials could also be improved in the future to reduce learning curve. Overall still very much recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would really like to like this game, but, at least for now, there's just not that much there to like. It requires effort to make a game about managing a shop exciting, and Shoppe Keep isn't. There's large quantities of waiting around for anything to happen and occassional flashes of frantic shelf-restocking, but it becomes a repetitive chore very quickly.

I'll keep an eye on this game as it development continues, but, for now, I'd advise passing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is good. Not 100% amazing, spotless game, but it's good.

Everything you need to know about this game is;
- Build your shop, protect it from theives.
- Make profit on all kinds of different wares and equipment.
- Destroy all competition that stands in your way.
- Enjoy one of the most memorable games I've played in a while.

All in all, this game has tonnes of potential and I cannot wait to see how the devs roll this out. For the cheap price of £5, can you really go wrong?

Solid 8/10, get this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't know what to write, so here is the wikipedia page on a chocolate chip cookie.

A chocolate chip cookie is a drop cookie that originated in the United States and features chocolate chips as its distinguishing ingredient. The traditional recipe combines a dough composed of butter and both brown and white sugar with semi-sweet chocolate chips. Variations include recipes with other types of chocolate as well as additional ingredients such as nuts or oatmeal.

HistoryThe chocolate chip cookie was invented by Ruth Graves Wakefield. She owned the Toll House Inn, in Whitman, Massachusetts, a very popular restaurant that featured home cooking in the 1930s. Her cookbook, Toll House Tried and True Recipes, was first published in 1936 by M. Barrows & Company, New York. The 1938 edition of the cookbook was the first to include the recipe Toll House Chocolate Crunch Cookie" which rapidly became a favorite cookie in American homes.

Differing versions of discoveryRuth Wakefield stated that she deliberately invented the cookie. She said
date: "We had been serving a thin butterscotch nut cookie with ice cream. Everybody seemed to love it
recommended: but I was trying to give them something different. So I came up with Toll House cookie."A different version of events says that Wakefield is said to have been making chocolate cookies and on running out of regular baker's chocolate
hoursPlayed: substituted broken pieces of semi-sweet chocolate from Nestlé thinking that they would melt and mix into the batter. They did not and the chocolate chip cookie was born. A still different history of the cookie derives from George Boucher

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Man it sucks to throw a negative review on Shoppe Keep; after playing for 30+ hours, however, I feel like I've seen more than enough of the game to be informed enough to discuss it's merits.

Quick pro's and con's:

Pro's Unique Idea
Initially a LOT of funCons Busy work that lasts your entire play through
Singular dimension
Shoppe Keep follows suit of games like Recettear, allowing the player to manage a shop for adventurers to get some items (potions, weapons, and armor). The premise of it, and initial outlook, are a lot of fun! Setting up your furniture to display your wares, scrounging around in trash cans, launching thieves into the air with your lightening. You slowly accumulate wealth, which allows you to purchase more furniture, display more items for sale, and expand your shop size.  It isn't a bad premise.

The first issue that absolutely destroys the game is busy work. This involves picking up items that customers remove from your shelves (for no reason other than to force you to pick it up, and give you a task while it's open). Once your shop is displaying 50+ items, and your customers throw 20 items everywhere in the first three minutes, it becomes a headache. It's been proposed to further drop the prices: at 130%, it still happens to frequently to be worth dealing with.

There was what appears to be a proposed fix, in the form of allowing robots to pick up the items for you (among other menial tasks these robots can accomplish); however, the robots cannot understand your floor layout, so you can throw your inventory quotas to ♥♥♥♥, or you can not use them. Even with using them, you still ave to remove each piece of gear from the robots and place it back on the shelf.

The second busy work is sweeping. Yeah, you get a little broom, and every customer that comes through your shop, on top of throwing your ♥♥♥♥ all over the place, track mud everywhere. So you sweep all day. This has seen an attempted fix, however, in the form of highly expensive floor mats that are destroyed after about 60% of the day passes. Which can give you a leg up in picking up all of the ♥♥♥♥ everywhere, but you'll go back to sweeping before the day is done. And after the day is done. And sweep up all of the corpses.

After receiving some advice from the forums, I reattempted to get back into Shoppe Keep, but did so with a stop watch so I could measure the amount of time spent doing busy work" and the amount of time spent actually managing inventory
recommended: and the shoddy questing/champion system (more on that later). Of an hour and a half of play time
hoursPlayed: I spent 78 minutes doing busy work. It becomes tedious
voteText: to say the absolute least.\n\nSo then we have the singular dimension I've mentioned. You never see anything but the store. You never do anything but increase your wealth and buy more things. Then sell the things you've bought. On top of sweeping and picking up the damn items. They have something called a champion that you can unlock
helpfulPercent: and send him on "adventures" (which consists of you clicking a GUI to send him to a location
votesHelpful: and then reading the quest log). You can try your hand at gardening
votesTotal: which consists of clicking at dirt and waiting ~5 minutes.\n\nI'm not mentioning the bugs because it's still in development
votesFunny: and it's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to call out a developing game for those. They could sweep me off my feet and change a LOT before release. As of now
commentsCount: just go play Recettear.\n"

Linux version seems to be a lot more buggy than other versions (at least that's what I'm guessing based on some lets plays). You're going to experience:

I know it's early access and it's supposed to be buggy, but that's a new low for me. Can't do anything without being forced to deal with bugs.

reviewText:
A neat idea, like a 3D first-person version of Recettear. I like shop managment games and gave it a try. Tutorial is a text list (with one screenshot per function), leaves out vital information. For example, it took half of my 50 minutes played to figure out that the controls for raising/lowering prices only work when the items in question are in the inventory chest, not where you pick up the item or where you place it. When the item was placed I got frustrated mashing the keys for raising the price with no effect. So I learned over the course of 25 minutes that you have to pick up the item from the delivery chest, deposit it into the inventory chest, change the price there (and only there), pick up the item again, and place it on display. Not only is it a clunky mechanic, it's undocumented. I'm sure at one point the player surmounts the learning curve and has fun, but the developer doesn't help and I am no longer interested in trying to figure it out. 2D graphics are great, 3D graphics are fine (store, items, furniture etc.), but the customer and player models are awful and the textures look like they were created in MS Paint.
Refund requested.

Suggestions to the developer:
1) Rework some of your quests into a short series of basic functions that walk the player through vital tutorial info with prompts. This will get new players past that frustration point where they quit (and ask for a refund, as I did).
2) Fully document not only the key bindings, but the narrow set of circumstances under which they are functional (i.e. must be in this mode, used only from this location/container, etc.)
3) Last and least important, improve those player/customer models and skins. They don't look great in the screenshots, and they look even worse in the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game is interesting and fun (if you like this genre of game...) the lack of any clear guidance is really weighing it down. I have had to look up youtube videos of other people playing just to learn the controls because, god forbid they put a keymapping option in game. The tutorials don't work for PC and the quests don't seem to work... unless they do, and i don't know how to turn them in.

The meat of the gameplay is fun, it keeps you on your toes (dang thieves) and it presents relative simplicity for newcomers but can definitely become harder late game.

I do not recommend this game NOW, especially for somebody who is not tenacious about looking up HOW to do things, but in the future I would definitely recommend.

reviewText:
Tried getting a refund for the first time since I've become a Steam member, but was denied. I honestly think the 2 hour maximum rule is BS. I guess I'm stuck with this game, so here's my experience so far...

First of all, do NOT waste your money on multiple tables in the beginning. If you don't have the money for Health Potions, you might as well start over, or else you're going to have to wait until you find an item in the trash to sell. Health Potions are the cheapest items you can buy and re-sell at first. However, the only table available to you that can hold potions has a 1 item limit, so starting out is goin to be a slowwwww one. There is a shelf that can hold what I assume to be 9, but I have no idea how to unlock it.

There IS a leveling system in the game, and I'm sure that's what is needed to unlock more things to buy, but the game doesn't specify. I think I'm level 5 now, but I still haven't noticed any benefits from it.

One other thing I've noticed is that you can't set a price for individual items. What I mean is, let's say I want to sell a Health Potion (which is valued at 10g) for 150% or 15g and I want to sell an item I found in the trash (valued at 100g) for 125% or 125g. The problem is, you can't. Every item's price is going to be based off of the last item you set down, which is frustrating because I have expensive items that I can't seem to sell since their price is too high! Yeah, I know I can just sell them cheap and then put my selling" items back on display AFTER
date: but how is that supposed to work in the late game
recommended: when dozens of people are coming in and out?\n\nI'm not trying to say this is a BAD game based on my demand for a refund. Honestly
hoursPlayed: it's a fun idea. I just think it was released too soon. I'm sure the bugs will be fixed in the near future
voteText: but I'd rather own a game that I know is 99.9% bug free."

reviewText:
Go buy a finished game. Not one that releases after years in early access, then goes to v1.0 with missing features like key rebinding (currently in the game, AFTER release).

These guys havent cared for months. They just pushed the release because it was ocnvenient. They've been doing events and con-special items instead of desigining their game. Heck, just 2 months ago they re-re-re-redesigned some features of the game, and last I checked they were still incomplete.

The game has a few hours of fun, and some grinding. And they'd rather pander to the kids crying about how good/ bad a feature is than to design it ONE way and stick to it.

Is it worth $9.99? If a few hours (or possibly more depending on YOU) sounds appealing, than sure. I had more than enough fun to justify my purchase a LONG time ago.

Don't mistake me having gotten my moneys worth for RECOMMENDING a game. Just telling you how I feel about my experience with this game, and the devs behind it. It's a lost, unfinished cause. Sorry if you disagree. It's called an opinion :D Cheers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The idea behind this is cool, but this needs to go in a slightly different direction, which I don't see happening at this point. Shoppe Keep is fairly cut-and-dried - you run and maintain a shop which includes dealing with wily customers and pillagers. Overall, things feel too 'floaty' to me and while this graphic style is sometimes ok IMO, it is not working so well here. I don't mind the micromanagement, but it seems like 25% of the customers are trying to steal. The other issue is that the choice in game modes, or 'levels' in this case, is not really put together that well.

Pros:
+Yeah its fun running a shop

Cons:
-I don't like the fighting aspect
-Graphics could use improvement - they don't need to be better... Just different?
-Some of the textures look like place-holders at this point (I am thinking of the order sheet, among others)
-Needs perhaps more statistical details and bookeeping that would come with running a shop (more depth in general)
-Sweeping is fine, but its too constant

I'm real 'meh' about this title - wait and see what happens in future updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My initial review was negative because I found one game mechanic in particular very frustrating (thieving). Just to explain this a little - NPC's will try to steal things from your shop sometimes, just by picking it up and running outside. You can't go outside yourself, and some counters are placed very nearby the entrance so it takes around 1-2 seconds for a thief to run off. The frequency of the thieves made some scenarios thoroughly miserable.

You can unlock skills by playing the game which cut down on thievery and even allow for a rechargable magic barrier which will make thievery almost none existant. This made me wonder what the point of thievery was in the first place. It was a mechanic that gave me 3 hours of annoyance and frustration that has now been nullified completely.

I don't want to wipe thievery from the game, I just want it to be fun!

I still can't recommend the game at the moment, because of the issues like;

1) Many scenario's are Sell 10 X and 20 Y". The frequency of sales is low and the things you'd expect to help
recommended: when you have lots of money in the scenario and decide to sell everything for 1% of the original price
hoursPlayed: there's no Black Friday rush. It's just the same - long and drawn out. The Developer has said that there are some mechanics behind the pricing but it's not readily apparent to me. It's obvious when you've priced something too high
voteText:
but there's never a low enough price to get the( effect you want.)

2) There's no progression in My Shoppe. There are scenarios to play that unlock new items but there's nothing to spend your gold on. It just feels pointless.

3) Barbarian attacks are every five minutes
helpfulPercent: and can be almost as annoying as thievery. Especially when you consider that your sword does AOE damage and if you accidentally break a counter in a Scenario
votesHelpful:
you can't replace it. That means that you might not have space to sell 10 of X and 20 of Y. That means that the two hours you already played are wasted.

The latest update wasn't really what I wanted to see. A small customization of your own character. I think they're dabbling with frequency rate of barbarians and things like that too.

Maybe I'm expecting too much for a low priced game? I mean it's basically a steal. It's just that I have always wanted to play a game like this
votesTotal: but with more rpg elements and progression/expansion and I would love to see My Shoppe become that."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A note for Linux UsersAs the title implies this review is only aimed at Linux.
(Please read; I would recommend this game for Windows & Mac Users)
At the moment there seems to be an issue for some Linux users when playing this games, it appears the mouse doesn't lock, this means when the mouse hits the edge of the screen/window you can no longer rotate your character. This bug makes the game almost impossible to play, though you can pause the game (or perform any other action that would allow the user to freely move the mouse in-game) and manually re-center the mouse, then unpause the game every time you hit the edge of the screen. Personally I don't think this is a viable fix, it prevents a player from really becoming imersed into the game. This is the reason I sadly cannot reccomend this game at this moment in time.
Please remember this review is only based at those using Linux and NOT those using Windows or OS x

reviewText:
Ok so first of all, this is not a release version. It's barely a beta, and considering the fact that it has been in early access for quite a time, it's also an insult.

Full controller support ? Lol... Can't even navigate in the menu or create a shop without switching back to keyboard and mouse.

When you create a shop, it just goes back to the menu with nothing to let you know what todo next, and you have to click play again to see you shop and start a game.

Tutorial is so boring you end up not reading it, and therefore, not being able to understand the mechanics of the game. And even though you're brave enough to read those, i hope you have good eyes and like typo changing because they're written with a really small, or really big, or really medium font. I don't even understand the logic behind that.

There is a hint when you look at the floor of you house. Because... Reasons. And this hint will not disappear until you read the appropriate tutorial ! Great, great idea really...

Do not try to get out of your house using the door. Doors are for weak people, try the hatch on the floor instead...

As far as I've played, there's only one friggin' music which is so repetitive that it seems to loop every 10 seconds.

Graphics are not that nice and barely ok.

Don't you dare alt-tab the game because you won't be able to access your task bar.



I'll try it again if it ever gets finished, but for now, it's a big disappointment and i really don't recommend it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is still early access so I'm reluctant to be too critical, but it really has a long way to go. The camera is seriously janky to the point where when someone steals your crap and you have two seconds to notice them, run after them and kill them, you probably spend most of that time running into the same table. You get almost used to it after a bit, but at first I thought I was gonna get motion sick. The tutorial is seriously lacking, and probably should tell you basic things like where the items you buy will actually appear. I got an achievement for completing the first scenario which, in all honesty, I didn't come close to doing. I literally purposefully failled it to see if it would give me hints on how to play. I'd definitely wait for some more improvements before buying this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR This game basically has all of the charm of Magic Circle. ..Not the...not the GAME Magic Circle, the eventual end product that happens at the end of Magic Circle designed to parody terrible hack products designed to make a cheap buck off steam.

To be more specific, the control scheme is overelaborate and is based on switching between six different options each with their own submenus on the fly, the game's idea of a 'tutorial' is basically a stripped down helpfile, You can helpfully hit spacebar for a joke about being unable to jump that is funny precisely once, instead of making spacebar do something useful. What with it being a convenient button to press for a variety of functions. But no, let's make an endless joke about how you have an arrow in the knee and cannot jump. I assume from that that this thing has been in Early Accesss since Skyrim was trendy.

The gameplay drops you right in without any real guidnace, but I was able to faff about and eventually figure out NOT to buy any furniture except for two pedestals, upon which I placed one mana potion and one health potion. I jacked up the prices to 2 gold, only to have a customer flip me off for being expensive. I then figured out the problem.

2 gold (203%) was too expensive, but it turns out 2 gold (159%) was a perfectly acceptable price. I may have those percentages wrong, but the principle is still sound, customers can tell precisely what percentile you've raised the prices even if the actual gold cost remains the same.

So I kept going, as a stream of customers proceeded to gaggle into my store, stare at my two pedestals, frantically beg for flowers and vegetables, laugh at my prices, and then leave.

Wait, no, they didn't leave. They stood there for ingame hours, continually angry about my lack of flowers and vegetables. At least the satisfied customers OH RIGHT THEY STAYED TOO. Eventually I would murder some from time to time just to clear it up, as only 20% of my customers would leave at any given time.

So eventually I managed by the end of the first day to get to the point where I could cycle through pairs of gloves, and as I watched the outside world near closing time, the doors closed..trapping me inside. Not my shop, I was trapped inside the doors, and could not move, helpless to watch as I could not pay my tax bill, which...didn't seem to cause any sort of problem whatsoever. Perhaps the inspector was kind enough to realize I was trapped inside a wooden prison, able to see out but forever immobilized.

So yeah this game's <3<3<3<3ing awful.

reviewText:
I am generally a fan of cheaper, lesser known games. I like games that do not necessarily look the best, but have a unique charm. I had thought Shoppe Keep was going to be one such game.

I was wrong.

In Shoppe Keep you play as a shop keeper (go figure), running a shop selling items for adventurers. Having played Recettear, I thought this game was going to be a blast. And it could have been, had I played for more than 20 minutes. But I could not. I got as far as building my displays and placing some items before I became so aggravated at the clunky control system that I gave up. Even with rebinding keys, the entire GUI is just awful. I had to scroll (with the mousewheel) through my items, with no list to just click what I wanted. And when I finally found the item I liked, I picked up a different one to free up the spot on the shelf and it switched to the item I picked up! I never even made it to the part where I could sell stuff, because it was just unbearable.

The graphics in the game are not terrible, but not great. I have a feeling older computers could run this no problem, if it was worth running. But sadly, it is not.

The soundtrack was annoying, as well. At least, the one song that repeated and repeated and repeated while I fumbled around with the controls. Which really held back this game’s potential.

All in all, the game set my hopes high. But I never even got to experience the whole aspect that made me buy the game: selling things and haggling over the price until they finally cave because they actually do need a sword to fight.

Might try this game in a few months, if the UI gets an update. But until then, I do not recommend spending the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got a refund after playing this game for a bit.

The game sounds good on paper but there is no flow mechanism. It throws everything at you within your first minutes playing. I started the game for the first time and put up a couple of potions for sale. I kid you not, literally within one minute I was raided. It's not as much as a raid as it is full on invasion with an army of 200+ raiders - I only had a couple of potions on sale and they weren't even marked up that much. I died because the raiders can hit you through walls and the wall of their own corpses that builds up.

I realize this is in early access. But I think that having some type of logical flow to the customers and prices would be in the core of a SHOP KEEPING GAME. Unless this is some other type of game and I'm missing something here...

Early Access Review

I've played this game for a fair amount of time and thoroughly enjoyed it.

When it worked properly.

Unfortunately, there's bugs that have persisted for months on end that can lead to a complete loss of progress. Hours of progress despite the game assuring you that it's saved correctly.

For that reason, I can in goo conscience recommend this game to anyone in its current state, and I'm not sure I'll ever return to it, either. The developer has had ample time to address these problems, but it hasn't happened.

The concept sounded good but in all actuallity this game suffers from a few glaring issues.

1) The sound is bugged, it does work in scenarios but not from the main title screen and make sure you turn your volume down to 0 before you start it less you blow your eardrums out the side of your head in a smokeshow.

After 15 mins of trying to find my order I gave up and have now requested a refund, I would give this game awhile before you decide to get it due to these alone but it's your money do as you wish.

Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me? WORST UI EVER!

There's just no hint for how things work:

--[E] starts the day, once the day is started you can't place any shelves or tables, so if you pressed E by accident in the first day, the whole day is ruined -- you can't sell anything!
--Those objects in your backroom cant be interacted with. took me minutes to figuare out how to use any of them.
--You can't place a shield on a pedestal. This is pretty WTF on it self, but get this, nobody's gonna tell it! so you just sit there wonder why those green things stopped showing up.

The order window, as you can see in the video demo of the game, is a real world object! That made letters on the far side really small and hard to read.

Talking about hard to read, WTF is with the font? Just imagine every word -- instructions, labels -- that you're trying to read is in the font of shop signs, those fancy bulky letters. I mean isn't it obvious it just don't fit?

Also, when your customer say something, you can only hear or read their speech bubbles when you're REALLY, REALLY close to them. any further you won't hear anything, and the text will be just blurs.

Swinging Y axis by default. This is not even an action game.

The shopkeeper have 6 states"
date: the implementations are laughable:\n--The are called "states" in game. STATES!\n--Fighting state is only meaningful when the shop is open
recommended: it is avilable throughout the day. Same as building state is only meaningful when the shop is closed

reviewText:
I found this game during early access, at the time i wasnt interested because it wasnt polished enough but i put it on my list of games to follow. It came up on my news feed as launched and ive had some luck with indie devs so thought i would give it a chance.

As they sold this game to me as the finished prodcut i feel its only fair to review it as a finished product. This game isnt very good. The goal of the game i guess is to run a shop which means just sell as much junk every day to everyone to turn a profit and repeat.

It gets boring quick, and everything is very manual. For instance  you can buy a shelf that holds 12 small items, you have to manually stock it with those twelve items, and as they sell you need to restock each item, also apparently placing potions in a bookcase causes wear on said bookcase and must be repaired. If this was an alpha game i would say it has promise, as a final version, i wish i had read a couple reviews before i bought it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

would take a ridiculously long time to even be remotely happy with my store, hours upon hours of grinding for gold not to mention the scenarios ar crazy, 20 minutes of people walking in and out or staring at all my wares, only to either steal them. or just walk about the store and dirty the place up. its ok however the RNG for actually selling an item is ridiculous.

EDIT

when adjusting prices, it uses a percentage guage. When you hit 150% you go up to 2 gold on a 1 gold item obviously, before you get to the next gold price of 3, ALL percentages in between SHOULD be useless up until that point, AND here is why. From what I have learned, or experimented, The higher the price, the higher change the item will be stolen instead. And if a potion is selling for 2 150%. And you up it to 2 165%, the chance to steal goes up, however the price stays the same. Thus making it a little pointless, Though a nice feature to change percentages at such a small level. It becomes pretty crazy when selling things at higher prices or even 1 gold over for small items.

This game is quite good, I mean yes it is in early access, and has alot of game-breaking bugs in it. But from what i've seen, they update the game daily, so alot of these get fixed very quickly. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fiendishly addictive.  It's the sort of game where everything seems so simple, but can snowball into different layers of complexity that can keep you rallying behind the game even in the darkest hours of fantasy retail.

Whilst it can become quite a grind, that somehow seems to add to the addiction, as you're determined to do well in your business endeavours, in spite of opportunistic thieves stealing your best stock, marauding barbarians smashing up your furniture, and the tax man demanding he takes all of your petty cash, just when you thought you could make a great stock investment with it.

The art and animation style is fun and endearing, the music is, whilst quite repetitive, strangely hypnotic and pleasant.  The overall theme works very well and has me hooked.

For a pre-release game (at the time I am writing this), it seems like a very well polished product, and I can only look forward to any additions the developers plan to add.

Right, now I have to get back and restock before opening time.  Excuse me!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHave you ever been really Jealous of those Shop Keepers in RPG games. Now is your chance to be on the other side of the counter. This game lets you run your own shop. It is like they took the Pawn Stars iPhone Game and mashed it together with all those old RPG games we used to play. You start off with 25 Gold then you use it to buy items to sell to all those adventurers. Things like Potions, Swords, Armor etc. You choose the mark up but if its too high your patrons get angry and trash your store. Take the profits use it to by more items and displays and repeat. You can expand your shop and you will need to fight off shoplifters and barbarians. You can purchase power ups which give you additional bonuses. Despite all the cool stuff the game is still seems incomplete. The developer is active in the community and for 5 bucks how can you go wrong? I think this game has tremedous potential I can't wait to see what Kris does with it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While beginning, things are quite slow and steady. Maybe even a bit boring at times. However, it is still a good game. Unfortunately, this game has some issues to work out.

1: DIRT. A LOT OF IT. So much that you will spend more than 50% of your time sweeping the ground. Sure, you can purchase a floor mat to help, but they break within a minute. Floor mats should last MUCH longer. Maybe at least half a day of dozens of people walking in and out every second.
2: Day/Night cycle. I just got a bug that broke this. Upon the day ending, the doors did not close, and nothing I could do couold reset the day/night cycle back again. Couldn't skip using the watch, couldn't press e, nothing. Fix that.
3: Jumping. Not that much of an issue, but it would REALLY help with mobility. That's my recommendation. Screw that stupid message that pops up when you press the space bar.
4: Staff NPC's. This could really help, since you're just a single player trying to manage a shop for which there are DOZENS upon DOZENS of customers. Some cashiers, some restockers, that sorta thing. The Help Bots that cost 900 (base and bot together) is kinda helpful, but not much.

If you can get past all these, though, then it's a fun game. I really enjoy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Off the line, this is an addictive,  fun and  pretty casual game.  make your shop, play for half hour, then save and then come back to it.

Spend an hour or a few(which is easily squandered).  manage prices,  rob your customers, manage stock, maintain your props,  gain expereince and gain new skills, grow plants and apparetnly craft stuff,  keep an eye out for thieves and then fight a horde of barbarians... On top of that, you can equip a hero to go loot some nice equipment for you... As shallow as this game does seem on the off, there is plenty to do and plenty of life and depth in this.  I am unsure how deep it goes but am keen to spend more time to determine that.

Its true, its in Early access, so more stuff is being added, like the quests/scenario section being merged into the free-play  'MyShoppe' mode, which I think is a great move from the devs; For an early access game, at this point, I think its pretty decent.

This is not perfect by any means but it still does alot of good things in my book.  So far, this  indie game is pretty fresh and is a very pleasant and easy to grip, gaming experience...  which is, if not too hard to drop once you have started.  The music is quite pleasant too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, this game unfinished, is really fun, but after a few hours it gets really boring, here's why.

Cons: At first, the low amount of money makes it seem like you can sell a lot of stuff, but really once you gain lot's of money, theres not that many things to sell. Glitchy NPC's can wreak havoc on your store, and helper bots rarely help stop theives. Also, I believe a better way of building should be developed, maybe whenever you go into build mode, the floor turns into a grid, this allows precise building and symetrical shops. It gets laggier the bigger your shop gets. (Duh.)

Pros: I can easily waste hours playing this game, it's super fun. At first, theres lots of things you can get, and you can do really cool things with the items the game provides. This game is humerous, and I feel the dev's would be really friendly people IRL based on how this game was created.

Meh?: Once you start getting lot's of money it gets boring due to nothing to buy. The amount of dirt the customers bring in, is just uncanney. The graphics are nice, the choice of textures, are not. (They should be customizeable.)

Tldr; Support this game so they can fix the bugs and push out an amazing time killing game.

Tip for the dev's: MULTIPLAYER WOULD BE SO FRIGGIN' COOL.
