reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is a fun little game well worth the price. You start off really small with maybe a few pedestals on which to pedal your potions and make a few gold. After you've sold enough potions you buy a table so you can sell bigger and better things, and before you know it you're running any RPG player's favorite supermarket.

Pros:

+Excelent music, after several hours I never got bored of listening to the game's soundtrack
+Very good art style, the graphics aren't very good but the game is still nice to look at
+Kind of addicting, I love starting this game up every now and again to sell some items and watch my shop grow
+Selling items is very satisfying, the cha-ching of gold being made is a very hard sound to get tired of

~The game has some pretty hilarious graphical glitches with dead bodies that I love to exploit, not sure if this is a pro or  a con for some

Cons:

-Pretty buggy, but there are no game breaking bugs I am aware of. These are mostly graphical and don't impact gameplay a significant amount at all
-Perhaps a little too easy
-There are a few seemingly useless mechanics in it, such as the grinder and the cauldron. I never used these and my shop still makes bank.

The Verdict: Excelent game in which to sink a few hours and have a pleasant time. I hope the devs still update it often and keep improving it. I can definitely reccomend it in it's current state, most of the game is done and is very enjoyable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game a lot, and I still on the fence. This game has a lot of potential and is different than anything i've played before. The biggest issue is the user interface for me. Granted this is early access, doing things in this game is not easy as it should be (easy to understand, hard to get the game to 'do' what you want).

Pros:
1. Fairly unique game play and interesting premise.
2. has a lot of potential.

cons:
1. User interface is clunky and currently buggy.
2. Not easy to manipulate items you buy (like once you buy a pedestal or shelf, if you accidentally place it the wrong way, it's not easy to fix. I sold a 100 gold weapon stand, and got like 3gold back from selling it....wtf.
3. Once a ton of people go to your shop, it's so easy to steal your stuff.

Recommendations:
1. Need to be able to hire guards.
2. Need to be able to hire sweepers.
3. User interface should have a dedicated button for all functions.
4. Need to be able to open/close when needed.
5. Would be better to start off really small, like with just a stall (instead of a whole store). Work your way up from a stall to a shop.
6. Queue multiple orders.
7. Need to balance price/cost and have fluctuating demand etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is a fun little game well worth the price. You start off really small with maybe a few pedestals on which to pedal your potions and make a few gold. After you've sold enough potions you buy a table so you can sell bigger and better things, and before you know it you're running any RPG player's favorite supermarket.

Pros:

+Excelent music, after several hours I never got bored of listening to the game's soundtrack
+Very good art style, the graphics aren't very good but the game is still nice to look at
+Kind of addicting, I love starting this game up every now and again to sell some items and watch my shop grow
+Selling items is very satisfying, the cha-ching of gold being made is a very hard sound to get tired of

~The game has some pretty hilarious graphical glitches with dead bodies that I love to exploit, not sure if this is a pro or  a con for some

Cons:

-Pretty buggy, but there are no game breaking bugs I am aware of. These are mostly graphical and don't impact gameplay a significant amount at all
-Perhaps a little too easy
-There are a few seemingly useless mechanics in it, such as the grinder and the cauldron. I never used these and my shop still makes bank.

The Verdict: Excelent game in which to sink a few hours and have a pleasant time. I hope the devs still update it often and keep improving it. I can definitely reccomend it in it's current state, most of the game is done and is very enjoyable.

Early Access Review

this game is better then i expected, well worth the $7.50, i was expecting to get a fairly repetetive game where all you do is stock stuff, but it adds a whole diferent angle on things. you know those rpg games where you don't care about the shops and you think they have boring jobs, this makes you respect those guys, you are always quite a bit scared that someone will steal from you, you gotta keep stock in, and you gotta armour (sry im canadian) up a hero. heres some pros and cons

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Date: Dec 23 2015...

While the game is still in development there is definitely makings of a great game. Instead of the adventurer that ventures out in the world to discover things, you play as the shop keeper where adventurers purchase itens from you. You have to defend yourself against barbarians and thieves, all while making sure your shop inventory stays stocked and your furniture is functional.

Like I said the game is under development, so it isn't finished yet and I haven't fully progressed through what is out yet. I am a huge fan of the game so far and am looking forward to the full release.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Indie game is amazing, with great gameplay, and awesome devs who listen to the community and work extremely hard to pump out amazing content

Gameplay
The game starts out very slow. You get 60 gold, and a very small shop. You start small, buying cheap items and making a small profit. But, the game very quickly becomes much more diverse and fun. You start buying new, more expensive items, you start crafting, sending your hero on challenges, and most importantly, you start growing weed. You can eventually buy expansions to your shop if you have enough money, making your shop much bigger.

Updates and Devs
The Devs are very dedicated to this game, pumping out regular-ish updates with lots of content added in each. The most recent was the Winter update, which added a much bigger outside area, progressive gameplay, and all out much better graphics. Like MUCH better. They are constantly looking for new ways to improve their game, and they definetely succeed at it.

Final Rating
Right now, the game still has lots to work on, but it has so much potential. At this moment, I would give it a 7.5/10, but it has the potential to become a 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At $5, this game will suffice for a handful of hours of entertainment in its current state. While it is a bit buggy, and some things just plainly aren't implemented yet, the current early access version (as of 9/24/15) is fun, challenging at points, and satisfyingly modular.

The devs appear to be heavily involved with the community, and at $5, this would actually appear to be an EA purposed at funding development, rather than being a premature cash grab.

If you enjoy shop sims, RPGs, or fun and relaxing games, I would pick this up.

10/10 would buy 100 times over, just to see where it goes next.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fiendishly addictive.  It's the sort of game where everything seems so simple, but can snowball into different layers of complexity that can keep you rallying behind the game even in the darkest hours of fantasy retail.

Whilst it can become quite a grind, that somehow seems to add to the addiction, as you're determined to do well in your business endeavours, in spite of opportunistic thieves stealing your best stock, marauding barbarians smashing up your furniture, and the tax man demanding he takes all of your petty cash, just when you thought you could make a great stock investment with it.

The art and animation style is fun and endearing, the music is, whilst quite repetitive, strangely hypnotic and pleasant.  The overall theme works very well and has me hooked.

For a pre-release game (at the time I am writing this), it seems like a very well polished product, and I can only look forward to any additions the developers plan to add.

Right, now I have to get back and restock before opening time.  Excuse me!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very interesting. It's still in early access, so you have to take that into account for sure. I really enjoy this game, it adds new exciting mechanics to a shop-owner game, like keeping the place clean and maintained and defending from attacks. I think it would be cool for there to be people who you can give quests to (like shop keepers do in a lot of games) so that they can bring back certain special items for you to display that give better appeal or special bonuses, or maybe crafting items. That's another thing too, item crafting would be very cool, instead of just ordering items and selling them, maybe it would add a bit more interactivity with the items.
Couple things I noticed that I didn't like, although it gave me a laugh and made me enjoy it while it happened, is the customers (peasants?) walk up to me, pick me up over their heads, and drop me behind them! They could just say excuse me and walk around! Also, the dirt that they track around seems to be a bit much. I understand when they come in, but after 5 minutes wandering around the shoppe, they shouldn't be tracking so much around.

I found it to be very hilarious, it definitely gave me a laugh! I like this game and will continue to play it for sure! Thanks for the game, and keep up the great work with it, I can't wait to see what the future holds for this game!

I made a video too, if anyone is interesting in seeing! Plus there's more on this game, and will continue with more!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZZoJvVhQnKY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: This game is an RPG/management sim has the *potential* to become the most appealing game I have ever played.

Getting to design, stock, and run your own store is such great idea, I am surprised it has not been implemented before (that I've seen). Assuming this game does not become abandoned by the developers, this will become one of my highest played titles. The game is, at it's core, an exponential management simulation. The game captures the best part of any management sim, which is the ability to create something you're proud of and then sit back and watch it flourish. My favorite thing about the game is that it can be played at any level of concentration; if you focus completely on the game you can run your shop optimally and make tons of money; or you could just simply let the game run in the background, occasionally returning focus to restock some shelves and sweep up.

This game is quite good, I mean yes it is in early access, and has alot of game-breaking bugs in it. But from what i've seen, they update the game daily, so alot of these get fixed very quickly.  Plus, if you take a look at the trailers, there appear to be alot more things on the way, I,E. a resource manager, more types of robots, more classes, upgrades and more.

I'll let you guys decide if it's worth your time, but i'd say for 5 bucks, it is.  7.5/10

update 9.02 review/ 420 update:
So for me, the update came out this morning,and i am quite impressed!  seriously, it was a big content update. first off, the reason i know this as the 420 update,is because they added the ability to grow weed, i'm guessing it's a different kind of weed but still.  It also is teasing at livestock out back of your shop, so maybe things like pigs and cows?  And the shop has gotten a complete makeover,as it now has a much larger back room, and the action to extend sections of the shop.  although i have one thing i found. i believe that in the next update the back yard will be unlocked, and you'll be able to farm crops, as alot of customers have been asking about fruits and vegetables.
Good job Kris and Otto, you guy's have made a wonderful update. new score: 8/10 much better than before and shows even more potential now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anything written here is subject to change as the game is updated.

Shoppe Keep is a sim" of sorts where you take on the role of a shoppekeeper starting out in an empty two-room shoppe. Over the days you take small profits earned and invest them back into the shoppe in the form of new displays
recommended: and of course purchasing new inventory. Unfortunately
hoursPlayed: it's not an incredibly deep game as of yet. There is a system of crafting that is rather convoluted and will require a guide if you want to actually make an item rather than waste money. There is also a champion in your shoppe whom you can send out on quests resulting in either new (potentially rare) items to sell
voteText: or a KO and a waste of your investment.\n\nThe soundtrack is good
helpfulPercent: if a bit samey (you'll be hearing the same few pieces several times per play session)
votesHelpful: and the game has a sense of humor to it. There are definitely aspects that need to be fleshed out further (and I suspect they will be as the game is developed). Additionally
votesTotal: there are some quality of life updates that would go a long way to make the game more enjoyable (e.g. an ability to sort your inventory).\n\nDue note that there have been some major bugs during development. The devs have shown that they're on top of getting things fixed as soon as they can
votesFunny: but you will still possible experience points where the game is very frustrating to play due to bugs. Shoppe Keep is quite clearly an example of a game much earlier in development than some others that have been bade available for Early Access.\n\nAll that said
commentsCount: this is a fantastic concept
column16: and thus far shows really strong promise. It's very much playable as-is
column17: and can be very engrossing if you let it get there. It's not particularly deep as of yet
column18: but it's definitely deep enough to get your money's worth."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its a great game, simple but fun. However I have 1 main problem, that could be split into two. And thats balancing.

The early game potions are good, but mushroom seeds are incredibly cheap (18 gold) and the grown mushrooms sell for a base amount of approx 90 gold. Which means within 2-3 days you will be able to have over 1k gold, which is a huge amount. The skills are also incredibly cheap, as you could have all of the skills before the end of day 2. Which means you could essentially finish the game before the end of the first week. And as each day seems to be at least 10 minutes, but probably more, there is not much (that I'm aware of) to keep you going.

Of course as the game is still early access these could all be easily remedied in the future. But otherwise there are few, if any bugs in the game right now.

And the best part of the game is jumping. Seriously, try it. Jumping makes the game soooo much better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPeople who gave negative reviews are too entitled to what they want for 7 bucks. The game has been updated and fixed to where there are no game breaking bugs, the only problem is the Helper Bot gets stuck in corners sometimes. This game is really fun and kind of unique. First Person perspective of building and maintaining your own fantasy/medieval shop (as you can see from the videos). Sell potions, upgrade shop. Sell weapons and armor. Craft, enchant, and modify weapons and armor, sell for more gold. It's a great, playable game. Thieves will come and steal, but it isnt too bad because you can, A. Chase them down the street and kill them. Or B. Spend a few XP and get an electric barrier for theives to be blown to bits before they get outside. Barbarians will come and try to destroy all you have worked hard on. Get the advantage by fighting them outside. Rinse and repeat, make more gold, sell more items, upgrade your shop. Not a bad game in the state it's in. Just needs more items to buy/craft and sell. Good enough to spend time while waiting on WoW queues or dailies to reset. That's all I have to say about that. Cheers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: My review was originally negative, as seen below, however a recent update seems to have addressed these issues, and with these 2 fixed I would now recommend the game.


ORIGINAL REVIEW:
This game is really fun, I found myself playing it for 3 hours straight the first time without realizing it. However... There are so many game breaking bugs that I just can't recommend it as it is. The 2 main bugs I've experienced are The shop refusing to save your shop, even when you click the 'save shop' button. And the second is the shop not closing for the end of the day, that combined with the first bug can undo an hour of work. And both these bugs have happened to me the last two games I've played.

I'm sure this will be really good in the future, i even find myself going back to it now even with these bugs, but right now, i can't recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to be an adventurer like you....

Once growing old or other circumstances mean that you are unable to quest as you once did, I could not recommend more that you open up your own shop rather than joining your local city guard. That way you can have hour after hour of enjoyment as you peddle your wares to prince, pauper, knight and knave.

Be your own boss, choosing what to sell  and where in your shop to place it. Hate wizards? Don't stock any mana potions. Want to get straight to the point? Only sell swords! Think your back wall keeps looking at you funny? Knock it down!

So far Shoppe Keep has proven to be an interesting and entertaining little game where you get to run your own shop, your own way. I can't wait to see what the developers do with the game as time goes on.

10/10 would recommend at this price.




PS. Look down while limping around your shop to help explain why you are no longer the questing type.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While beginning, things are quite slow and steady. Maybe even a bit boring at times. However, it is still a good game. Unfortunately, this game has some issues to work out.

1: DIRT. A LOT OF IT. So much that you will spend more than 50% of your time sweeping the ground. Sure, you can purchase a floor mat to help, but they break within a minute. Floor mats should last MUCH longer. Maybe at least half a day of dozens of people walking in and out every second.
2: Day/Night cycle. I just got a bug that broke this. Upon the day ending, the doors did not close, and nothing I could do couold reset the day/night cycle back again. Couldn't skip using the watch, couldn't press e, nothing. Fix that.
3: Jumping. Not that much of an issue, but it would REALLY help with mobility. That's my recommendation. Screw that stupid message that pops up when you press the space bar.
4: Staff NPC's. This could really help, since you're just a single player trying to manage a shop for which there are DOZENS upon DOZENS of customers. Some cashiers, some restockers, that sorta thing. The Help Bots that cost 900 (base and bot together) is kinda helpful, but not much.

If you can get past all these, though, then it's a fun game. I really enjoy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first game I have written a review for. In short, if you like RPGs - Buy This Game. It isn't actually an RPG, but the setting and things you sell are in that realm. I would define it as a Store Simulation game. It is a very fun game.

When you begin a game the learning curve is STEEP, but do not let that deter you. In my shoppe at around level 5-6 I COULD NOT keep up with the customers!! Wizard's Hats were flying off the hat rack!!! Never thought I'd get rid of those robes, though. Gloves sell pretty well, too. Just don't get greedy and try to sell too high.

Try to thief-proof" your shoppe ASAP using the points that you gain from playing. And keep that floor CLEAN. And Repair those displays

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I almost never write reviews, but this game warrants feedback. I absoultely love it. I'll place a basic list of pros and cons that should suffice anyone unsure of making the purchase.

Pros:

- At $5 USD this game is WELL worth it
- More video and audio options than expected
- Clean, easy-to-use interface
- Progression system featuring several unlockable skills
- Barbarians will attack; however, they're very easy to thwart
- Farming plots are available for you to grow three products
- Several objects may be purchased and placed freely to display products
- Additional rooms may be purchased to expand the size of the store

Cons:

- Barbarians take literally two hits to kill; making them little to no threat
- Thieves will steal from you even if you're standing directly next to them - this feels very unrealistic
- There is a severe lacking in the items you can sell - I believe roughly 20 - 30

Now, I do understand that this game is early access. Hopefully some of these issues will be addressed, along with the bugs. I myself have encountered only one bug so far, and that's with the doors to the shop not closing; causing the game to stay on that day and never progress. The only solution I've found is to completely restart. I BELIEVE this is caused by floor mats. Any time I place a floor mat, the following day the bug occurs. Maybe that's the solution?

Overall, this game is well worth the purchase. If you enjoy management games, drop the $5 USD and give it a try. You likely won't be dissappointed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHave you ever been really Jealous of those Shop Keepers in RPG games. Now is your chance to be on the other side of the counter. This game lets you run your own shop. It is like they took the Pawn Stars iPhone Game and mashed it together with all those old RPG games we used to play. You start off with 25 Gold then you use it to buy items to sell to all those adventurers. Things like Potions, Swords, Armor etc. You choose the mark up but if its too high your patrons get angry and trash your store. Take the profits use it to by more items and displays and repeat. You can expand your shop and you will need to fight off shoplifters and barbarians. You can purchase power ups which give you additional bonuses. Despite all the cool stuff the game is still seems incomplete. The developer is active in the community and for 5 bucks how can you go wrong? I think this game has tremedous potential I can't wait to see what Kris does with it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is a fun little game well worth the price. You start off really small with maybe a few pedestals on which to pedal your potions and make a few gold. After you've sold enough potions you buy a table so you can sell bigger and better things, and before you know it you're running any RPG player's favorite supermarket.

Pros:

+Excelent music, after several hours I never got bored of listening to the game's soundtrack
+Very good art style, the graphics aren't very good but the game is still nice to look at
+Kind of addicting, I love starting this game up every now and again to sell some items and watch my shop grow
+Selling items is very satisfying, the cha-ching of gold being made is a very hard sound to get tired of

~The game has some pretty hilarious graphical glitches with dead bodies that I love to exploit, not sure if this is a pro or  a con for some

Cons:

-Pretty buggy, but there are no game breaking bugs I am aware of. These are mostly graphical and don't impact gameplay a significant amount at all
-Perhaps a little too easy
-There are a few seemingly useless mechanics in it, such as the grinder and the cauldron. I never used these and my shop still makes bank.

The Verdict: Excelent game in which to sink a few hours and have a pleasant time. I hope the devs still update it often and keep improving it. I can definitely reccomend it in it's current state, most of the game is done and is very enjoyable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game a lot, and I still on the fence. This game has a lot of potential and is different than anything i've played before. The biggest issue is the user interface for me. Granted this is early access, doing things in this game is not easy as it should be (easy to understand, hard to get the game to 'do' what you want).

Pros:
1. Fairly unique game play and interesting premise.
2. has a lot of potential.

cons:
1. User interface is clunky and currently buggy.
2. Not easy to manipulate items you buy (like once you buy a pedestal or shelf, if you accidentally place it the wrong way, it's not easy to fix. I sold a 100 gold weapon stand, and got like 3gold back from selling it....wtf.
3. Once a ton of people go to your shop, it's so easy to steal your stuff.

Recommendations:
1. Need to be able to hire guards.
2. Need to be able to hire sweepers.
3. User interface should have a dedicated button for all functions.
4. Need to be able to open/close when needed.
5. Would be better to start off really small, like with just a stall (instead of a whole store). Work your way up from a stall to a shop.
6. Queue multiple orders.
7. Need to balance price/cost and have fluctuating demand etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, a gem that's extremely rare to find. The only other game I can think of that was close even if for a bit is Recettear. I love the soundtrack, the art, the idea, the game is even stable for an early access game, it's very promising. I highly recommend it since this genre is very rare and it's crazy fun to play, but I will list what I don't like about the game rather than what I like about it.

My problem with the game is that it gets repetitive very quickly. Cleaning the floor after customers gets extremely tedious, and the matt can only save you for one period of the day (Morning period). I wish we could have someone to help cleaning, returning items to their place after getting thrown away by customers. Add an employee option and put a daily payment to him as a salary. The shop gets big, way too big and there's no way to just manage everything by yourself.

The other thing is stock, I wish we can control which stock is for each spot (table, cabinet, etc) So when we buy new stock we don't have to go every damn time to put the new stock in the spots while you have to also clean the floor, return items after being thrown, chase thieves, buy new stock, I mean there's a limit to what one man can do. It might sound like I want this game to be easier, but no, I want it to be convenient but still challenging, I own the shop but it feels like I am being punished rather than running a shop. Then I end up having a fortune I have no idea what to do with, because if I make my shop bigger, I will be sufferring, money becomes irrelevant and profits don't feel rewarding at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Addicting. Just bought the game and i've already put 4 hours in it. For the 7$ I payed for it, I would suggest it to anyone and everyone. The game is clean fun, great for children and adults alike. It does have some lacking features, but hey, what game doesn't while in Alpha. If the game were to do something with a barter system outside of your shop, maybe competetion with other shops, or even multiplayer with friends, that would set it off completely. But not to jump topics too much, the game is great and is going on the right track at being a game of its own kind.

What to expect:
Slow mornings, over bearing days, some glitching AI at times (pathfinding directly into my right wall that hasn't been torn down.), and I found this hilarious, TONS of women thieves. I laughed pretty hard after my first thief, which was a male and after that i've literally played 3:30 hours more than that and i've had NOTHING but women thieves. Anyway guys, keep up the good work on this game, it's worth the buy for sure and I hope to see more updates coming through.

What to fix:
When you are adding the audio, instead of making it load at the location where you press space, try making it set to your camera. That will allow sound to travel with your character.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever wonder what it would be like to not have to go on all those annoying adventures?

Ever felt envious of those lucky shop keepers, who get to live the luxurious life of selling junk?

Then Shoppe Keep is the game for you!



Seriously though. Its a retail simulator with a unique twist of letting you play as a store owner in a medieval fantasy RPG setting instead of the normal modern setting.

Some RPG-like elements have come over in gameplay as well as the games setting in the form of level ups, perks, etc.

You also get a sword and some magic to take care of those pesky thieves, who think that just because they're the towns hero they can steal from you (at least they don't try to put a basket on your head).

Overall its simply a fun and quirky game that both simulation and RPG lovers are sure to enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1:
*order supplies to sell and shelves to put everything on
*open for business
*first customer comes in and buys a health potion-success!
*more customers come in, get mad, and keep throwing my products
*another guy walks in, throws a potion down, and starts to leave
*i get mad, run after him, and stab him with my sword
*onlooker sees me murder him, so i kill him too, along with another bystander
*i clean up the bodies and continue business
*i sell all of my stuff
*night comes and i close shop for the day

10/10 would kill rude customers again. :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shoppe Keep is (in it's current early access state) a really fun little game.

It can fill dozens of hours without you even achieving much. Yet it stays fun all the way.

There are still some minor little bugs but nothing gamebreaking. My major complaints have even been fixed in todays patch. It's always nice to see that devs are really working on the project and listen to the community.

If you like Trading games with a little building or rather designing in it you will definitly like this game.

My personal major selling point for the game was it's first person gameplay as I haven't played something like this before and it brings the shoppe to a total new and better form of life

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game, just grindy as heck. You need over 5K in skill points not including the 2K extra you need from the main menu from other things. The game requires you to do a lot of repeat things like sell, restock, and buy. As per the name: shoppe keep. You own a shop.

I can recommend this for adult who are bored but not for people that want fast progress as the game is super grindy. There isn't a lot to do other than buy, sell, restock. You get something called keep points, you will nmeed that to expands and keep playing. However it will not hold your attention. The game devs seem to be at a point where game updates are slow because it all depends off of one human being. So this will be a 1 man project for an endless amount of time. It is in phase 2 of developement. Many bugs harbor it. You can't even play comfortably in high rez. So wait a wait until it's fixed. Too much broken stuff currently.

The game devs had a huge part into what they offer including the drug scene. I dont recommend this for children as you will be growing a lot of drugs for npcs. With that being said, there is no real emerision so I suggest waiting until this game has more to offer and keeping it away from children. Seems cool but doesn't have all the things I wish it did. It's kinda boring after you reach a certain point. You can't zoom out. With only 1 real dev, this will take yrs to finish.

I use to love playing this game till like 4 months ago they decided to update it and all the sudden it would crash the moment that i opened it. I emailed to developers and they told me i'd have to wait for the next update. Finally after checking it every week for an update, after about 3 months of waiting, they finally updated it so i could play. The problem is thier was way too many bugs and it was really choppy. This is really weird because i have a nice enough computer to play Fall out 4 on high graphics, but i can't even run this game on low. Every week i still check back when they update and  everytime i play it's still really choppy and the list of bugs keeps adding up. Its really nice that they are adding new content, but i feel like they should probably put some focus on making this game some what playable.

-Really choppy/lagging even with a good computer
-Everytime they update it thier is a new bug
-They never go and fix the bugs
-When you try and contact the developers to help fix things they tell you just to wait for the next update

Pros
-Constant content updates(Not much bug fixes)
-Fun game(If you can play)

reviewText:
I love this game. It's amazing and I love it. I've designed my shop how I like, and it's not limited to a grid. I do however have a few improvements and suggestions:

-Once a person walks over a floor mat, they no longer trigger other floor mats, because their feet are already clean
-This game become broom simulator 2015 after a while. I love it to pieces, but theres too much damn sweeping.
-Make more places to put stuff! Maybe a larger version of a Pedestal, or an armor/weapon combo?
-More Items are always good. Maybe some spell tomes or scrolls would be cool
-More weapons, such as maces or axes
-Make alchemy easier to understand, maybe have a way you can buy recipes?
-Seriously, There's too much damn sweeping. Its a big turn-off for me and I'm playing right now in the hopes that this issue will soon be resolved.
-I would love to see multiplayer eventually incorporated into the game, where you could set up shop across from another player and try to attract more customers.
-Posters on the walls. For example, Sips has played through the game and I know you're watching him, could we have a Doctor Yablonski's potions or something, Or even something where you could choose a Jpeg image to throw up on a wall for custom adverts
-More customization options, for example multiple shop layouts to choose from
-A way to name and customize your shop, to be able to have different signs for Branches" of your shop

reviewText:
So as of my review I have put 3 hours into this game, 1 over the refund limit. That's okay, I'll keep this buggy gem however a few words of caution to the less patient gamer(s) on STEAM...

tl;dr Buggy but shows promise, pick it up if you're not strapped for cash and enjoy managing your patience and shop simultaneously.

First off, the major turn off, we'll get this outta the way first. Dev's pay attention, this early deal breaker will frustrate about 75% of your early supporters and have an overall negative impact on sales.

- Controller ALMOST Supported. The buttons overlap one another and even the main cursor on the home screen disappears if you hit a left or right key at an inopportune moment. If you tap left or right while in game and do not have an item in hand, it'll stil affect the price change differential. These over-lapping commands can be very frustrating, especially in the in-game menus such as ordering and skills/perks and when trying to interact with customers directly while out and about in town.

i.e. I walk up to Warrior Smith and hit the action button, the dialogue box pops up however the default cursor position is nowhere to be found. If you hit up, right or left the cursor will just never appear no matter what other button combination you press and instead you MUST hit down to have it default to the center option of the three.

i.o.e. On the VERY FIRST SCREEN of the game, where you pick the controller option itself once you do you can hit the confirm button to get in after you hit up on the cursor pad instead of it defaulting to the start option and then once it gets into the main menu you must again hit right to get it to populate onto the options such as load game, new, ect and this persists throughout.


NOW, that's aside and fully detailed let's get onto the good aspects of this game and why I'd recommend this game (especially in its final form)..

- As a SIM game goes it's a good one. Granted I thought I was going to unlock new furniture by level but yet it's by K" points so I was a few days behind having proper shelving but that aside it's a decent RPG type Sim as in you sell Potions and Gear. This alone would make it worth $5 on sale because even a solid premise like this is hard to come by.

- Decent selection as you progress. Obviously you're going to sell the Plate Gear but people will still WANT the Leather stuff too. The balance could still use some tweaking but overall people still are generally okay with buying a decent spread of items if you allow your shop to have them.

- The game is growing and it appears the Devs are trying to fix things. This is a big plus

recommended: oh wait I hit a bump; let me take the small amount of money I made and scram because I'm in over my head" Game Developers that buy RPG Maker or some like engine on sale and make some rudimentary muck.\n\n- Music is catchy

- Once you get the hang of the bugs the game becomes fun. They will be fixed I presume and that's really the biggest drawback.


Now there are a few places that could use work...

- Obviously the graphics

- Quest / K-Points. First off

SO FINALLY! To those who made it this far let's give it the final breakdown!

Graphics? 3

Verdict? You'll spend $10 on something that'll be worse for your health in the next week than this game; at least you'll enjoy this longer.

What else can I say? If you have the spare money
